editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DRUDGE:
OR The Jealous Extravagant.
A PIECE OF Gallantry.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, at the Blew Anchor in the Lower Walk of the New Exchange. 1673.

div.head: TO THE Right Honourable THE Lord BUCKHURST.
div.p:
THe cribling Gentlemen of this impertinent Generation, in depite of all the damning Criticks of the age, that very much oblige the Dramatick Tribe with continual matter for their Prologues, are come to that impudence as to write till on, and
uher in a bad Treatie with a wore Dedication. This is grown o familiar to the fine Men of the Town, that for all can be aid, will till be mot damnably opinionate, that the poor fool, that mut needs trouble himelf with the turning of this foolery, was reolved out of meer complaiance to do as the ret did, and then out-rival his fellows too both in nonence and Impudence, which your Lordhip mut needs avow he has mot egregiouly performed, when he aumed the vanity to make your Honour a preent of uch a trifle. That
incomparable Judgement, and Ingenuity that your Lordhip is even to a miracle endowed withal, will very much advance the vanity of the proud Tranlator; the mot accomplihed wit of the age may have jut caue to tremble when he expoes his mot abolute and perfect pieces to the cenure of your Lordhip, (this is a truth that the whole Kingdom is concious of, and the Turner of this Gallantry was not ignorant of if) as he may jutly defy all the world, when he has once acquired your Lordhips approbation of it, but
ince my French Author was my preident, and had o good an eteem for this piece, at to judge it worth the acceptance of their Royal Highnees of Savoy, I uddainly reolved to purue my Tranlation, and trancribe his pride of well Gallantry, and that I might aume ome liberty to my elf, have made it omething the more nonenical (it is poible it may pleae the better) by prefixing an Epitle to an Epitle, and Dedicating a Dedication. Your Lordhip will be graciouly pleaed to excue this gay nonene,
and pardon o extravagant an addres, which you can only impute to your Noble elf, whoe very name is o charming and attractive, that I was hurried on by an Entheuiame of mad Zeal, to Court and Embrace (as I would Health and Happines, or what ele is dearer to me in the world) this blet occaion to ubcribe my elf.

closer.signed: Your Lordhps mot obedient Servant. J. B.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
I Should do the Monieur, thee, and my elf a mot damn'd injury, hould I honour this trifle with the title of a Tranlation; that word that ounds o gloriouly in this pretty Frenchyfi'd Generation; and I hould be as vain as a Poet is in his Prefaces, his Ejays, his Prologues, his Epilogues, and their Apologies, hould I
ay 'tis my own, and a whole Shoal of Englih Monieurs, with a Morbleu, Diantre, &c. would wear it was the Zelotide, and eaily detect the Fallacy; what hall I do then with this Monter of a Pamphlet, this Mongrel piece of Gallantry, that has lot every thing that might make it lovely and agreeable? it has lot the nuffling Idium, that great accomplihment in a Gentleman, and is infected with ome of the Englih cutoms too; but faith, pardon it, for I'le aure you 'tis very fahionable: Here's Kising
and Dancing, &c. here are Treatments and the Fidles; here are gay, brisk, and Airy Girls too, and the Jilts have uch a charming wildnes, that it mut needs take you, 'tis not posible to be avoided. And if all thee Ornaments of a fahionable Treatie, are not enough to et off this poor omething, what Name or Title oever you hall pleae to give it; I know very little in the world. But if all this cannot recommend it to your Charity, & ilence the damning Criticks of the age, I'm very confident I have that will
mightily pleae the fine Gentlemen of the Town: here's no damn'd, dull, out of fahion Matrimony in the concluion, to poil all that went before. Our Gallant, if he be in Love, it is in a very Honourable way, he till preerves his Liberty, and his Love, that is, he is yet unmarried, for after that ugly thing is once arrived, that has detroyed o many beautiful Affections, and pretty pasions in the world, you hall carce find ought or either. In a word, 'tis at your Mercy, name it, and
cenure it, damn it as you pleae, if you can have the heart to damn any thing that is originally French, and when 'tis made Englih, is as mad as the bet of you.

div.head: TO Their Royal Highnes's THE DUKE and DUCHESS OF SAVOY.
A Sonnet.

lg.l: SWeet pair of Royal Lovers that in pite
Of damn'd, dull Matrimony, till are o,
That in chate Kies can till take delight,
Nor do thoe lawful weets inipid grow.
You from the plagues of Marriage till are free
And after the firt month your life commend,
Your Kies mack as well as formerly,
Nor can his Love, nor can her charms have end.
How from o brave a ource can chue but pring
Or Kings, or omething greater then a King?
What Blesings for your People coining are:
Could but my pretty fretful Zelotide
Advance your Joys, and reinforce their Tide,
How I'de applaud the Jilt, and doat o •…

div.head: THE DRUDGE.
TO His Royal Highnes THE DUKE OF SAVOY.

p.U:
hould be an enemy to my own glory, hould I not endeavour to acquaint all France with the happy detiny my fooleries have found in Piedmont. I heard from Turin, that they had the honour to arrive at your Royal Highnee's hands, and the happines to divert you; and that you were pleas'd to think my Picture worthy to take up a place in your Cabinet: What an infinite Honour, Sir,
mut it needs be to one of my capacity to have diverted a Prince, that nothing, that was not uncommon and extraordinary ever yet could, and to find room in a Cabinet, where nothing but precious things are admitted; ought I after o ignal a favour vouchafed by your Royal Highnes, till to give my Proe and Vere no better all treatment then that of Fopperies? ought I after all this, to depie the productions of my young Mue. No, Sir, I dare not purue that my cruelty. And I hould believe I injured the oundnes of your jundgement, hould I preerve my contempt of that, which has merited your eteem. Thus am I now enforced to deert all my modety at once, and grow as proud as o illutrious an approbation, as your Royal Highnes an poibly make me.

div.p:
And really, Sir, who dare condemn this pride in me, when they hall conider whence it took its original? and who dare aume the rahnes, to be of a different opinion from your Royal Highnes? if any Critick durt now condemn any thing of mine, I would appeal to your Royal Highnes as a Soveraign Judge in matters of this nature, and this Soveraignty is not les coniderable, Sir, than that which your Royal Ancetors have poes'd, and left you inveted in, as their worthy Succeor: It is more glorious • o have a Soveraignty over the Wits, than the Rabble. Heaven indeed has blet you with a coniderable advantage in conerving a Crown and your Life together upon you, but it peaks you her particular Favourite in endowing your Highnes with all thoe Royal qualities,
which the management of that Crown with Glory required; and one of thee Qualities, Sir, and that not the leat coniderable, is your incomparable Ingenuity.

Thoe Princes that Reign no other way then by their Authority, have no other advantage, than that of being fear'd of their Subjects, but thoe that Reign with Mildnes, with Magnanimity, and the Troop of Vertues they are adorn'd with, have the happines to ee themelves belov'd, repected, and ador'd by their People. And 'tis this, Sir, that gets you the Love, the Repect, and Adoration of your Subjects; when ever they peak of your Royal Highnes, 'tis with entiments of Veneration, and with tranports of Zeal for your Service and Honour, which plainly hew, how agreeable your Empire is to them, and with what incerity they bles Heav'n for the weetnes of your Reign over them. Your Birth has made you their Prince, but if your Royal Blood had not et the Crown on your Head, had it been in their power, you would have receiv'd it from their free E
• ection.

We being their near neighbors, have often Commerce with them, and in their convera
• ion, whereof their Soveraign makes the mot charming and agreeable part of it, we ee them very often open their hearts to us, and peak their thoughts with freedom, in which pleaant converation, Sir, they have o well expres'd that zealous repect, which they preerved for your Royal Highnes, that they have communicated it to me. I could not chue but have as
great a paion as the bet of them for a Prince o truly amiable, and one belov'd by all the world with o much jutice, and were I not a Subject of the greatet King in the world, I hould wih your Royal Highnes for my Soveraign.

But, Sir, I hould abue my elf, hould I make that wih; is it not a happines I already enjoy? and am not I your Subject and are not you my Soveraign, although neither Piedmont, Savoy, nor any other of your Dominions be my Countrey. You enjoy a Soveraignty, that extends it elf farther then the bounds of your Provinces, which procures you Subjects in all the reaonable parts of the world, and makes your Dominions as large as that of the Mues. This Empire, Sir, thoe nine immortal Ladies have etablihed you in all places where they have any interet, to tetify their acknowledgement of thoe many Favours your Royal Highnes hath made them receive. The good entertainment you oblige them with, is an infallible igne, that you are not ignorant of their Beauties, and that you have a perfect knowledge of their Merits.

We ought not to wonder when we ee them but little eteemed in a great part of the world; none can eteem them but thoe that know them, and that is an advantage that Heaven doth not commonly betow; your Royal Highnes is mater of this precious advantage, and I am very certain that you poes it in a very eminent degree; that quick, ubtle, and delicate Wit of yours, is skill'd even to admiration, in all the polite, and pretty things in the world, and pierces into all the ecrets of our Parnaus.

This is that Divine Quality, Sir, that gives a Lutre to all your Heroick ones, and crowns you King of all the Wits of the age: Your Valour, Jutice, and Generoity are great Virtues I mut confes; That weetnes and obliging entertainment, with that agreeable Air which accompanies all your Actions, and Charms all thoe that have the Honour to approach your Royal Peron; that Galantry which is o natural to you, which gets you the inclinations of the Ladies, and renders your Court, and all your divertiements o Noble and Magnificent, are glorious advantages, I mut avow it. But all thee coniderable vertues and glorious advantages, would, it is poible, be confined to your own Dominions, and Strangers, and Poterity would never o much as hear of them, were they not attended by that our Love of the Mues. Had it not been for this Honourable inclination, Augutus never had received o many Elogies as he did, and his Glory, it may be, had never reached our Ears. It is this that makes your Vertues commended and talkt of beyond the limits of your Provinces, and hall do too, far beyond that hort coure of your life, that you pend o gloriouly, and that merited Eternity; it is this that invets you with a Soveraignty over all the Vertuoi in the world, and to which I am obliged for the happines I enjoy, to tile my elf your Subject. It is poible it is an exces of vanity in me to reckon my elf among the Wits; but when one has once obtain'd the happines to pleae your Royal Highnes, he may without arrogance aume that glorious Title with all its appendages,
and in that condition to which your Royal Highnes has been pleaed to advance me; I hould offend your judgement, hould I have a bad opinion of any thing that I call mine. I have o highly eteemed my parts, ince I was informed your Royal Highnes did not depie them, I judged them capable of conferring omething, to your Royal pleaure.

Since my firt works have taken the boldnes to pas over the Alps without my Commiion, and yet had the happines to pleae all your Court, though I durt not hope it; I imagined, that thoe I hould my elf end over thither, and which had no other deigne but that of your Royal Highnees Divertiement, would not be o unhappy, as to come off wore then the former.

It is a great deign without quetion, that I engage upon, and I hould ay even a rah and inconiderate one, if a peron had not advied me to it, that I am confident is too prudent to counel me to any uch undertakings: it is, Sir, a Gentleman of your Dominions that hath the honour both to be known and belov'd of his Prince, that hath been pleaed to give himelf the trouble to bring my Mue into your Court, and that hath wrote me word of the good entertainment it received from your Royal Highnes. This generous friend of mine could not poibly procure me a more glorious, advantage nor one that I more vehemently deired; but that which hath exceeded all my hopes, and created in me the mot pleaant urprize imaginable, is that incomparable goodne that he was pleaed to
have for me in communicating a Letter of your Royal Highnes to me, in which you graciouly vouchafed to witnes, that you eteemed my works, and that you hould be very well atisfied to ee me make ome more of them for your divertiement. This Letter was a Soveraign and indiputable Order for me, but it was no unpleaant one, and I can afely wear, I received it with as great a joy as ubmiion.

It is this, Sir, that obliged me to the writing of this piece of Gallantry, the gayety whereof it is not impoible may not dipleae you. It may be too, it may diipate for ome moments thoe troubleome thoughts, that your Politick affairs commonly leave behind them, and ome of thoe cares which the conduct of great Etates almot always plague us with.

If I can compas o noble a deigne as this, I hall get my elf reputation, and hall perwade my elf, that your Subjects are omething engaged to me into the bargain. It is not to be quetioned but they know, that when one diverted Cear, he obliged the Republick, and I am very certain, that Cear had not more noble qualities then your Royal Highnes; and that the Romans had not a more tender affection, or profound repect for him, then thoe of Piedmont and Savoy have for their Soveraign.

Thee are truths, Sir, that your Royal Highnes may eaily be atisfied of, from a forreign Countrey. If they were told you by your Subjects, you might upect, they aid o for their own interet, or to flatter you, and o receive their praies as a common homage, which people
eldom refue their Soveraigns; but when an Elogie proceeds to you from a Province not ubject to your Royal Highnes, you may aure your elf, Sir, that he who gave you thee commendations, was confident of the truth of them. It is from trangers that a Prince may learn infallibly, what Sentiments the world has of him, and what their judgement is of his Qualities and his Conduct.

And ince it is o, Sir, your Royal Highnes ought to be entirely atisfied; thoe strangers which are not intereed in your Highnes, praie and bles you; and I, Sir, that have made ome voyages into forraign Countreys, can witnes the truth of it: Whereever they peak of your Royal Highnes, they compare you to thoe great Princes from whence you drew your being. As all the world is very well atisfied that no danger can urprize you, and that your courage either acknowledges no dangers, or makes them immediately ceae to be o, they compare you to the Illutrious Amedees, which all the dreadful power of the Turks could never terrifie, and that preerved Rhodes with o much glory againt all the force of the Ottoman Emperor. They count you too, as good as that Louis, that was o much belov'd of his Subjects, for his weetnes and clemency, as wie as that Charles, urnamed the Warrier, that was as well the mot prudent as accomplihed Prince of his Age; as knowing, as that other Charles urnamed the Good, who o dearly loved Scholars, and Learning; and as quick and active as the great Emanuel
Philibert, that how'd o incomparable an addres in all his bodily exercies.

I have often heard your Royal Highnes compared too, to all your famous Ancetors, but mot commonly they do it with your Illutrious Grandfather, to that great Prince whoe name you own, and whoe Vertues you are mater of. In the time he lived in, he was eteemed a Man that had the mot glorious reputation in the world. rban the VIII, our Henry the Great, and James the VIII. King of Great Brittain, gave him commendations, that poterity hould never be unmindful of; and the great Cardinal of Richielieu, which knew as well as any man, all thee Vertues that are neceary for a Prince; aid of him, of whom I am a peaking, that he never knew a more trong, active, and univeral Wit in his life; the mot eloquent Mues of his time have ung of his Merit. That Tao that he loved with o much tendernes, the Ciabrera, the Marines, and Caines, thought they hould render themelves immortal, by inerting uch a Princes Commendations in their Works, whoe name and memory ought to be immortal. If all thoe great Men were till alive, I am confident, they would conpire to tell you, that the Charles Emanuel of our age, is a Son worthy that Charles Emanuel, that was o jutly praied by all thoe great Princes, and o bravely ung of by all thoe illutrious Poets. Why have not I the Wit and Eloquence of the lat, which I would wholly employ with all my oul to make an Elogie for your Royal Highnes. I'd tell the future ages of thoe Vertues, whereof ours
is o trongly perwaded; your great Spirit, I mean your Gcneroity, your Bounty, your Widom, and all your other Qualities; at leat as far as my Wit would permit me, that you have received them with the blood of that incomparable Conqueror Amedees, your Augut Father.

Since thee great qualities, which before were onely een afar off, were in your voyage to Lyons more nearly conidered by all our Court; our great Monarch has conceived Sentiments of Love and Eteem for your Royal Highnes, and thoe too are pread through his whoe Kingdom. And would not the French be injut, hould they not doat upon uch a Prince, which always exprees o great a love for France; a Prince, that no ooner aw, that his troubleome detiny had broke thoe ties that engaged him to our Crown, but he ought out for new ones with all the vehemence in the world: how infinitely reaonable was this vehemence, ince its Object was a Princes o accomplihed? a Princes whoe charms deerve o much Love, Repect, and Devotion, that in the greatnes of her Soul, is the accurate Portraicture of your Illutrious Mother, and that by her Vertues would revive her memory, if it was poible, that it ever could be extinguihed.

What a joy it was to your Subjects, Sir, to ee your Royal Highnes bound in an Eternal knot to that incomparable Princes? and what a glory it would be for me, if my Story were pleaant enough to divert two Perons of o high a Rank, and o ublime Ingenuity. I dare avow, Sir, that in pight of my accutomed inufficiency,
I conceived very great hopes of it. When one has a deigne to pleae you, 'tis very difficult to think of any thing that is low and contemptible; the Soul raies it elf in the undertaking o great an enterprie: and as for my particular, I believe that mine has excelled it elf, ever ince the very intant that I intended to make my Image of Zelotyde, becaue I had a deign to end it to your Royal Highnes, to preent you with all the Lineaments of her Jealouie, and gave all your Court a ufficient occaion to laugh at her upicious, and ridiculous apprehenions.

Hitherto, Sir, the Comedians have handled the jealous Gentlemen, with all the cruelty imaginable, and have commonly par'd the jealous Ladies. But for all that, there are ome of the delicate Sex as ubject to this paion, as the mot whining Romantick Lover among Men, and it will be convenient to acquaint them in this Hitory, how prejudicious this pretty Frenie is to their repoe, how extravagant it renders them, and how they deerve to be hated by all their Gallants, for this racally method of making Love.

May it pleae therefore your Royal Highnes, to cat an Eye on my pretty jealous Creature's extravagant adventures, which your goodnes makes me aume the liberty to make the recital of, and which I hall do with all the Gayety that my Subject requires, and with all the Repect I owe your Royal Highnes.

A general Peace was now concluded, to the extream dipleaure of the Gacoins, and this affliction had very much augmented that other, that the prohibition of Duels had caued them a little before: all their Villages were full of Reformed Officers, and the mot noble and brave among them, had no other employment then plaguing all they met with, with an impertinent recital of their Braveries, at God knows what River, and God knows what time. When the King iued out his Orders for the placing a Regiment of old Soldiers in one of the mot pleaing Towns of France; my intelligence could not inform me, whither this agreeable place we peak of, were on this ide, or beyond the Loire, but I dare aure you, it lies between Calice and Bayonne.

The greatet part of the Officers of this Regiment were not very well skil'd in any other Virtues, then their Military ones, and Wine and Tobacco, the Pot and Pipe was their chief employment: but all of them were not o candalouly inclin'd: ome few of them were more Gentile and Courtly, and preferred a handome obliging Lady, before all the Pots in Chritendom.

Our Lycidas was one of thee civil Gentlemen, and without all quetion, Sir, he might pas for one of the prettiet fellows in the Regiment; he was young and wity, and as well made as the bet of them; and to advance all thee accomplihments, his Cloaths were as fine, and Al-a-mode, as they could poibly be out of Paris; his
variety of Garnitures, and his good large plume of Feathers, that quite cover'd his little empty Noddle, made him preently be taken notice of; all the Ladies mightily admired him, and doing as they ue to do in the like occaions were infinitely taken with him, and there was not one Lady in all the Town, that was not hatching ome amorous deign, how to imprion this our handome tranger.

As he was alwaies a profet Servant of the Ladies, and he long'd to ee all the Beauties of the place, in as hort a time as he could; he, to forward his deign, got acquaintance with a Cavalier of the Town, that had formerly been a Soldier too, and now at preent.

This talkative ill-natured Cavalier, I forgot to tell you what he was before, would not for all the world but have brought Lycidas to Mas, that is the amorous rendezvous of the Town; and 'tis very likely had not Lycidas been acquainted, that he hould find good tore of Beauties there, he would have been more gentile, and les candalous than to go to that place of Devotion. Here it was a Man might ee at once all that thought themelves handome; and it was here that our Courtly Soldier learned all the names of the Ladies, for he was better bred then to cat an Eie, or peak a Syllable of any thing ele, while there was omething like a Woman in the company. This is very fair you will ay, for the firt bout; but our Gallant goes further, and learns what Love intrigue this and that Lady has with that and the other Gentleman, and in as hort a time as can be imagined, his precious
intelligence made him a perfect relation of their Loves, with all the drolling and railery his ill nature could upply him with: o that Lycidas, thanks to his talkative Buffoon was immediately acquainted with all the Bed-tratagems of the Town. After o hopeful a beginning, you may wear he would not leave off, he went continually to Mas, and that out of pure Love too, I dare aure you, he came always dres'd as fine as hands could make him; all covered over with Ribons and Feathers, and placed himelf in a fit Pot to have his finery taken notice of, and there, ometime tanding on one Leg, and then on the other, he plaid the prettiet tricks, and et his Face in o agreeable a poture, you would not think it; and let all this pains might be lot, he took a particular care he might be taken notice of.
div.l: His Eies tood alwaies Sentinel to pie
The am'rous looks of all the Ladies nigh.
Now on this he darts a glance,
And then on that he looks, as 'twere by chance,
To put the bluhing Lady out o'th' Pray'r;
Some pretty Creature chanc'd to cat aray,
He with a gracious Air return'd the glance,
He mil'd, and then tept back, and then advanc'd.
And to confirm their good intelligence
Not to deert the Beauty he admir'd
But thank her with an humble reverence.
div.p: In a word, Sir, he was the mot civil obliging peron that breath'd, Nay, faith, Sir, there are ome will tell you, that his very civility grew trouble ome and impertinent, he had o much of it; but for all this, take him all together, he was a very extraordinary peron, at leat people thought him o, for he grew to be the only talk in all company; the Ladies remembred all his hape, his Cloaths, and above all, his Carriage; and the pleaant Gentleman did not forget that neither, epecially his profound cringes, and his reverences Al-a-mode: the young ones grew o taken with him, that they mut needs try to count them, and becaue 'tis likely that one could never do it, there were many of them about it; two or three were to reckon up all he made with his right Leg, and as many more to count thoe of his left.

But for all thee puny fools plagu'd him with their damn'd dull railery, the mot accomplih'd Ladies of the Town would not mis the Mas for a Treat and the • iddles; the Church was never empty, and all this, becaue, our obliging Soldier was a contant Church-man. When they were come home again from their Devotions, all the Femals fell a thinking that he was more looked upon then another, and that the brisk Gallant had made her three or four alutes more then the ret; whence gathering (as thoe pretty Sophiters eaily deceive themelves) that he was preferr'd before the ret, he grew confident, that he hould effect the conquet of the Gallant, that all the Ladies deir'd. Among the ret, that never fail'd to come to Mas, Zelotyde
was one of the firt, and mot eager: She was a tately proper peron, young, and omething yellow-hair'd, and her Air and Mein had omething in them extreamly taking.

lg.l: When in the Church he did appear;
How her fair Eies of Eies attractive were,
And like the Sun no Star was een but her?
From her weet violence
Altars prov'd no defence,
Her acrilegious charms pull'd captives thence.

div.p: In a word, where ever he was, none could be een or look'd upon, but her; and all this, he term'd the effects of her Beauty, and perwaded herelf, that he really merited a greater eteem then the ret. She, as well as the ret had ome ill deign on our new Cavalier (but, I'faith, I think I'm out there, and a Captain of the Infantry cannot be well called o) and having reolv'd upon it, he dreed her elf with more care then ordinary, and forgot not any of thoe helps, that Art could furnih her with, to et off thoe advantages that nature had made her receive.

The Lady being uch as I have decrib'd her, your Royal Highnes may eaily imagine, that he had enough of Lycidas's humble reverences; wherever he met him, and that at Church, he particularly oblig'd her by his amorous glances; and I vow, 'tis well he did o, for the poor Creature, had he not given her that eteem he thought he deerv'd, would not have eaily been comforted for her misfortunes; he had indeed as quick a wit, as any Lady in the Town, but he had a very trange kind of humour though.
Her jealouie was o exceive, that he grew jealous of all the world, nay, of thoe perons he never knew, nor heard of, neither Friends nor Enemies could cape her; I have heard a hundred pretty tories of her Jealouie, of one of her acquaintance, and they're all extreamly pleaant and extraordinary. She was o damn'd jealous.

lg.l: If ome kind doating Husband chanc'd to kis,
What now he call, d his Wife, before his Mis;
And Zelotide but chanc'd to pie,
The mutual charming Language of their Eie;
She dams, he cures their chat Fire,
And longs to ee their purer Flames expire.
Who ever does cares, what e're it is,
Be't Wife or Mis,
She frets, he pines, he ighs,
To ee the conquet of another's Eies,
That any Face but hers, could make uch victories.
If the fond Lacquey chanc'd to kis the Maid,
Or by ome pretty ign his Love betray'd,
She the poor Innocent
Did mierably torment,
And Rival-like, till thwarted her intent,

div.p:
But yet, Sir, he did not do all this out of any averion he had to love, but the covetous Creature would have had all the world doat upon her; he would be the only Beauty, and the only Mitris of all that could conceive that noble paion. She went indeed ometimes to ee a Play and ometimes he would read Romances; but all this onely augmented her calamity, and thee
pretty divertiements were the greatet plagues in nature to her. At a Play he would fain get Celadon from Florimel, or Dauphire from the Collegiate Ladies, and could not endure to hear Romeo compliment his Juliet. And then in Romances he was confounded, mad to ee Pyrocles o paionate for his Pamela; he could with all her oul have trangled the fair Caandra, to get her Oroondates: All the actions of thoe fabulous Heroes, that they perform'd with o much Courage and Generoity to expres their Love, and do things worthy of it, were o many fatal blows that tab'd her contentment; and in that transport of fury, that their amorous declarations had put her; he threw away the Romance, nay, and ometimes threw it into the fire too, to revenge her elf for that injury, that he fancied had been put upon her: but yet he had ome wit with her madnes, at leat, o much as to conceal her extravagance from the eyes of the world, o that you could not poibly dicover it in her, without a long and a familiar acquaintance.

Having now learn'd her Character, your Royal Highnes may eaily imagine, what an intolerable trouble he was condemn'd to every day at Mas, where Lycidas never fail'd to meet her. For though he had the greatet hare of his amorous Glances, his Reverences, and all thoe petty pieces of Gallantry, he grew tark mad, and all this would not content her.

lg.l: If the fair tranger chanc'd to cat an Eye
On any pretty Creature nigh;
She rag'd, he torm'd, and wore they both mut die.
Thus ev'ry thing he aw conferr'd,
To heighten the misfortunes, he indur'd,
If the next Lady did without deign
Receive a glance or two,
As any pretty thing from Lycidas might do,
She torm'd, and would his Eies to her confine.
His glances, his alutes are all her own,
And he robs her, that does receive ev'n one.

div.p: Nevertheles her jealous Ladyhip was fain to conceal her reentments for ten or twelve days, for Lycidas was o long without viiting the Ladies at their everal Houes, and our Gallant did not this without all the reaon in the world, for he knew very well (though my intelligence did not inform me, how he came to know it) how much a man expoes himelf in company, when he is ignorant of their Intrigues, which make the greatet part of the dicoure, and for this reaon he reolv'd to be fully acquainted with the tory of the Town, before he engaged in company. And truly, that Gentleman Hitorian, that ill-natured Satyrit, I mean, that I told you of before, was as good a Mater to intruct him, as he could wih, and one that proved very neceary to him in that conjuncture, and upon this conideration (for faith I know nothing ele could induce him to it) he was carce ever out of his company.

In a fair day they both went a walking together, to enjoy the weetnes of the Air, and ee how the Spring had with her natural Artifice, (that you will ay now is a trange one I hope) painted all the Trees and Meadows with her inviible
Pencil, beyond the happy curioity of all the Italian Angelos; they went, if I am not mitaken, to a certain Garden not far out of Town, and when they came to the Gate of it, they aw two Coaches there, which made them upect there was company in the Garden wherupon they enquir'd of the Coachman, who told them that a kinman of our Cavaliers, had Coach'd ome even or eight Ladies thither: Now who would not pity this poor Gentleman among uch a company of Women, were he nine times a Man, that's about fourcore times more than a Tailor, he could never be enough for them: Why, a hundred Mouths would be little enough to anwer them and kis them, and a thouand hands would not uffice to clip them, hug them, and hand them; but I leave the Gentleman to the mercy of the Ladies, and mut ee what the other are a doing. They had no ooner learn'd of the Coachman, what I told you of, but they both agreed very prudently to go eek out ome other olitary place, that would be more fit and proper for their purpoe, and without more adoe, were marching back again, when the Mater of the Feat chanced to pie them, and running to them to top them, he made ue of that civil piece of violence, we commonly do in uch caes, to engage them to come into this company. The Femals that thought one man to even of them, was mot intolerable, were not very much dipleas'd at the arrival of thee two Gentlemen; Zelotide, that was one of the company, and knew the Cavalier, went to meet him, pretending ome buines he had to tell him of, but it was
for nothing ele but to lay hold of Lycidas firt of all; her project took, the tranger fell to her hare, and he, being a very pretty fellow, and one that poke the finet things in the world, and having a very happy faculty to love when he would, or, what was all one, to make people believe o.

lg.l: He then reolv'd his parts hould not be hid,
And if he did not love, you'd wear he did.

div.p: And really, Sir, this firt enterview, while the treatment was providing, Zelotide had reaon to be atisfied with him. They walked a great many turns of the Allie together, and Lycidas being no crupulous peron in making his Love-Declaration.

lg.l: Swore preently ten thouand Oaths
Beides his pretty Faiths and Troths,
That from the moment he firt aw,
Her charms, her charms, kept all his oul in aw,
And gently forc'd him to accept their Law.
That though he corn'd his paion
And did his torments with contempt look on.
Yet he, yet onely he,
Should be the Empres of his liberty.

div.p:
He had not quite finih'd his protetations, when Dinner was erved up, and they were call'd to it down. It was then, if ever, that Lycidas made a good ue of his wit, and poke a thouand the pleaantet things that ever were heard, o that the company was extreamly pleaed with him; and Zelotide conceived all the joy
imaginable, to ee a peron that he had ome good will for, appear o amiable to all the world beides. But then her damn'd humour made her reflect, and think with her elf, that if this tranger took her o infinitely, her companions too might be more taken with him, then he deired.

lg.l: And though he lov'd thoe charms he did decry,
Both in his Lips and Eye
And all his beauteous harmony,
She wih'd thoe charms away
That might ome other Lady make their prey.
Let he hould love elewhere, or ele be lov'd,
What cruel mieries her poor heart prov'd.

div.p: Her trouble was till augmented, and his actions, as he imagined, jutified her upitions; for the Gentleman did not, as he expected, only chooe out the choice bits to preent her with them, but took as much care too to pleaure the ret, and did it with a pretty grace, that charm'd the company, and made poor Zelotide run deperate; and this was the reaon why they ate not long at Table, for our jealous Lady being one of the mot coniderable among them, roe up firt, and obliged all the ret to follow her. They walked for ome mall time in the Garden, and then all the company retired. Lycidas mann'd Zelotide home, and by the way, beg'd of her mot vehemently, the permiion to wait upon her Ladyhip ometimes, which he mot courteouly obliged him with.

They both parted very well atisfied with one another, and thought every hour an age till they met again. Zelotide was over joyed at her Conquet, and perwaded her elf, that now he had triumphed over the ret of the Ladies; and Lycidas was no les pleaed to have begun his Female-acquaintance, with the mot handome and coniderable Lady of the Town, and being yet ignorant of Zelotides ill humour, and believing he was no cruel Lady, he aured himelf, that her Husband being now at Paris upon ome important buines, his Love would find no oppoition.

lg.l: He thought he now might own his Love,
And that the charming Dame
Could not o cruel or inhumane prove
As to condemn his Flame.
Her Vertue and her Honour were
The only enemies his Love could fear,
For her weet Air, proclaim'd her not evere.
He thought thoe foolih Oppoites, his Love
Might well without a Miracle remove,

div.p:
In a word, Sir, he promied himelf all the pleaure imaginable from his new Gallantry, and never dreamed of thoe troubles it would ingage him in; on the morrow he put on the mot proper and becoming Cloaths he had, and expected with impatience, the hour when he might ee the Ladies; Well, at lat it came, though to his thinking, mot cured lowly; and the Gallant goes to my Lady Zelotides, where he found her, in his judgement, a thouand times
more handome then ever he was before, either at Church or the Garden; and he truly had done all he could to et her elf off.

There were two Couins of hers with her at that time, of which the name of the one was Melite, and the other Cleonia: both of them young, both handome, and both of the mot pleaant and gay humour, that ever you met with. Thee three amiable perons were very familiar, and carce ever out of one anothers company. Lycidas that had naturally a very brisk wit, and made the bet ue of it he could in all Ladies company he came into, and a pretty kind of ininuation, was immediately received into this handome Troop, and judg'd a very fit peron for their amorous commerce, and one that they might talk too without ceremony; o that Zelotide would not any longer conceal her elf, but poke to him in the name of the whole company, either this, or much like it.

IF we may credit all your protetations, Sir, we may well perwade our elves, that our company is not diagreeable to you, and that whilt you tay in Town, we hall omething oblige you in admitting of thoe viits you make us. It is our pleaure therefore to oblige you thus, and we receive you into our ociety, if you think your elf capable to perform ome certain conditions, without which, you hall never come among us. It is not improbable, Sir, that in that little time you have een us, you have made a very advantageous judgement of the merits of my Couins, and I dare aume the vanity to tell you, that no Ladies in Town ought
to be preferred to us, o that the Law we precribe you, cannot jutly eem too rigid and intolerable; to ee no Lady, and admire or love any thing out of Breeches, but us; you have got a very incontant mind with you, and I hrowdly upect you for a fickle peron, and one fit to abue all the Women you meet with: your amorous lies and pretty perjuries, I'faith Sir, I mut tell you our reolution; either renounce this humour, or our ociety, for they are incompatible; there are indeed in Town, ome things in Petticoats that will admit of your Courtly wenching actions, but faith Sir, we hall not; we are too concious of our own worth and excellence, to come in harers with perons o much below us, and we mut have you wholly ours, or not at all. Go, Sir, examine your elf, and ee whither you can endure to keep us company upon thee conditions; and I dare aure you, that if you can, you will not repent of it.

Lycidas did not forget one word of this Harangue, and though it had been longer, his attention would not have been the les. So trange a urprize, as this dicoure mut needs put him into, made him tand mute and immoveable, and he was atonihed to hear them make him uch a Declaration at the firt viit. But however, when he aw Zelotide had ended her harangue, I made her an anwer agreeable to her wihes; and though he had never been reduced to uch hard terms before, as to ee but three Ladies in a whole Town, he wore the Conditions were too reaonable and obliging to be refued; and though they had not engaged him to them, he hould have followed them out of his own inclination: And to confirm all this, he
vow'd and proteted, that they, though but three of them, were worth all he had ever een before, and that any one of them were enough to make a mot contant Lover of the mot fickle Man in Nature.

Zelotide was very well atisfy'd with his protetations, and infinitely pleaed for ome few days, to ee him mot regularly oberve his promies. And Lycidas had really not yet een any Lady, but thee three fair ones. But Zelotyde for all this Exces of fidelity in him, was not yet contented, for eeing he viited her Couins almot as often as her, he was extreamly vexed that he had not bin more precie in her Declaration, and he became as jealous of her Couins, as the ret of the Ladies; but he could not now civilly forbid him her Couins Lodgings; for being bound to them in a very trict kind of friendhip, he very often went to ee them, and was glad to ee her Lycidas there. Beides too, had he only viited her, i • would be taken notice of and her reputation might perhaps be blemihed by it; he concluded therefore, that it was an inconvenience he could not poibly avoid; and that he was engaged upon all coniderations, to let the tranger viit Milite and Cleonia; but oberving that the former of them had ome affection for him, and was very well dipoed to rob her of her Gallant, and o deprive her of the Honour of her Conquet.

lg.l: She fear'd her Eies, as conquering as they were,
Might to her terror eem les fair,
When her hard rigors taught him to depair.
Lycidas was for favours till,
Obliging Favours till enlav'd his Will.
Goodnes to Merits till he would prefer,
And the kind Lady was his Conqueror.

div.p: Being hurried on by this fear of hers, which was but too well grounded, he reolved to prevent her Couins Favours, and make ure of her Lover, that eemed yet in upence what to fix upon; o that having very happily found an opportunity to peak to him in private, he dicovered her thoughts to him, with all the freedom that he could; Lycidas promied her mot faithfully his eternal Fidelity, and for ome time afterwards, they lived in a very good Intelligence one of another; he often viited the two Couins, but with uch caution, that the jealous was out of the world to ee it. All was very well for ome days among them, but Lycidas mut have his wing again, and you might confine Fire with les difficulty, then his wandring Incontancy; he had not o narrow a Soul as to bound his happines, and he is jut of uch a humour as I hall tell you now.

lg.l: Not all the Beauties in the world could tye
His Soul to make it keep a twelve hours contancy
Free as the Mountain-winds he roves,
Both when he's lov'd, and when he loves.
Though Ladies cruel are
He till loves one without depair,
Nay ometimes he
Quits Favours for their petty cruelty,
And rather had be corn'd, then loe his Liberty.

div.p: Though Zelotide was indoubtedly the hand omet Lady of the three, and perhaps of all the Town too; Melite begun to pleae him better then he did; her Soul was more mild and obliging, and he imagined he hould endure a more eaie lavery under her, then the former, o that he reolved to turn unfaithful to Zelotide; and feeing that it was very difficult for him to be o, both becaue the two Ladies were almot always together, and becaue Zelotide was very happy at dicoveries, he reolved to make ue of Artifice, and cheat her for all her jealouie to her face; that is, to be her ervant in appearance, but to devote himelf really to the young and pretty Melite. He found his loving fair one of uch a dipoition, as very much advanced the plot and this good Good Couin of Zelotide made no concience to cheat her. In uch concerns of Gallantry as thee are, I can aure your Royal Highnes, that there are not many Women in France that tickle for their faithfulnes.

lg.l: She that would count it a damn'd Sin,
To teal a Ribbon, nay a Pin
From a meer tranger, would not make
A cruple to partake
Of her fair Siters dearet victories,
And make her Siters hare her prize.

div.p:
And truly Melite was no more crupulous then another, and he was overjoyed that he could rob her Couin o neatly, he never refus'd Lycidas, and after by a thouand amorous Oaths, that the Courtly Gallant was never paring of,
he had perwaded her, that he was the only peron in the world that he mot dearly affected, he very frankly confeed to him, that he had omething of Love for him too.

lg.l: And by a certain pretty method did
Dicover, though he eem'd to wih it hid,
Her unfain'd Love with uch a weet addres,
And uch a prightly wit
That none could doubt of it.
You'd wear 'twas true, nor than he made it les.

div.p: Now they are both in a perfect union, and both agreed to mannage the buines with all the Art they can; but to what purpoe pray? as if any thing could be hid from the eyes of Jealouie. Though Lycidas viited Zelotyde daily, and peronated the Lover as well as could be; for all his Artifice, he melt out his Infidelity, both by the coolnes of his Addrees, and that want of care he took to pleae her: whereupon, he earch'd out the caue of it, and was not long before he lighted on it; he turned pie over all their actions.

lg.l: She read it in their Words and Eies
And till confirm'd her Jealouies
By omething in it elf indifferent,
Which he till wreted to a bad intent,
She made it am'rous what e're 'twas meant.
Her eye till track'd 'em out
(Too faithful Scout)
And in two days o much of 'em did ee,
She grew more certain then he wih'd to be.

div.p: Immediately hereupon, he reolves to break with her Couin, what ever tir might come of it; but upon better conideration, he judged it better to diemble her reentments, and endeavour to retrieve her Lycidas, by telling him of his Ingratitude, and the injutice of his change.

One evening, when he was walking alone with him in a Garden where all the beauties pend ome part of the night in the Spring time, he thought he had now a good opportunity to tell him of his falhood; Lycidas, who thought he could always abue her into any opinion he would, began to cajol her as he ue to do, and to aure her of his Love and Paion, a hundred manner of ways: but Zelotyde anwered all his protetations with raillery, why all this to me, Sir, aid he, you mitake your elf ure, and think you are with Melite; have you forgot who I am, and dare you be thus prodigal of your kindnees in the abence of your Mitris; I vow, Sir, hould he come to know of this, I am confident he'd everely punih you. You urprize me Madam, anwered Lycidas, and I can't tell what to make of this, what the Devil do you mean it for, erious, or raillery? You cannot without injutice upect me of any Intelligence with Melite. 'Tis true, he is very amiable, but it is alo infallibly true, that ince I had the happines to love you, I never o much as thought to be unfaithful: I have een your Kinwoman, I avow it, and have made her ome viits, but you may bepleaed to remember, that I did all this by your order; and I dare afely wear upon a Book, that were it not for the pleaure I took in obeying
your Commands, I hould never have endured to keep one company, that I o little care for, and which, it is very probable, cares as little for me.

lg.l: If you had heard him wear,
You'd wear he faithful were,
For till he talk'd of Love and Faithfulnes,
He talk'd of nothing more, and thought of nothing les.
And did all this with uch a weet addres,
That none e're yet us'd more incerity,
To clear a Truth, then he to prove a Lie.

div.p:
But for all this, all his Rhetorick could not perwade Zelotide, for when he till perited to excue himelf, becaue he had commanded him to viit her Kinwomen, he interrupted him with a great tranport of fury; what ingrateful Man, did I Command you to betray me, and turn unfaithful? and did you in puruance of my command hecome a Servant, to that young brisk Jade, and leave me for a peron in all repects inferior to me? and do you take me for o eaie a fool as to believe all this? no, bae Man, I do not, I hall never believe it; what did you two when you were alone together, if you mut needs hew your Love before me: That affected coldnes which you eem to have for one another, and then ome cunning kind of looks that cape you in pite of all your affectation; your words of two meanings, that are only undertood by you and your Chronie, and then that care you always take to have your
Garnitures of the ame colour, to have all the new Plays and Romances continually from Paris to pleaure your Lady, your hugging the hornify'd Gentleman, and your ininuating your elves into his Love and Favour; your leaving Money after Play, upon the Board, to get the Servants your Creatures, your bringing alway Sugar-plums in your pocket for the Paraqueto, and above all, your petty quarrels when people are by, and ecret igns with your Feet, when you think no body takes notice of them; Thee Mr. Infidel, and a hundred things more, which I am ahamed to peak of, will not permit me to doubt of your perfidiounes. Go, for an ungrateful Man, as you are, that do not deerve to be poke to, though in reproaches and raillery, nor be honoured with a reproof, I hould, continued he, have revenged my elf on my unfaithful Couin; Did I not perwade my elf, that you would ave me trouble of doing it, and he would no longer keep you faithful then I have done; I too well am acquainted with your incontancy, and it was my unhappines I knew it not ooner, and was kept too long in ignorance, that Favours and Obligations dipleae you, and that they are the ready means to detroy your affections.

Then was a great deal of rage in all this Harangue of Zelotide's, but her lat words had omething more of weetnes then fury, o that they might well have touch'd with pity, a harder heart than Lycidas's, and he was truly very enible of her reproaches.

lg.l: He grew at her complaint compaionate,
And his incontancy begun to hate.
But his good oul, to give the Devil his due,
With uch compaion had not long to do.

div.p: Yet he till did all he could to prove, that her upicions were injut and groundles, and that he ought not to ret atify'd with appearances. But eeing hit obtinate denials the more enraged her, he at lat, avow'd his infidelity, and begged his pardon in the mot moving words imaginable; he forgot not Oaths, to aure her, that he would never again viit Melite, and promied her mot faithfully, to live exactly according to her precriptions; Though Zelotide had no reaon to believe his oaths any longer, he deired the truth of them o much, that he mut abue her elf into an opinion of his fidelity once again.

lg.l: His wit could now upply no jut excue
To jutify his damn'd abue.
But they that do the guilty peron love,
The wort excue do willingly approve.

div.p: And o he pardoned them, Sir, and they went out of the Garden in very good terms again. But the unfortunate Zelotide, that thought he had wrought miracles by her dicoure, and obliged Lycidas to a perpetual fidelity, had unwittingly given ubject for an Intrigue, that ince has plagued her ufficiently.

The Cavalier, Lycidas's friend, and firt acquaintance, was one that had no great buines to imploy himelf in, and therefore he made it his buines to eek it out; he was continually running from place to place, and where ever he came, etting all he met with together by the ears; He was in a word, one of thoe Creatures we call Fopps, Buie-bodies, contriving-Aes, &c. Fools that neither love themelves nor any body ele; Confounded Coxcombs that would willingly undo themelves, might they bury another in their ruines.

This vertuous Gentleman was very often with a company of Ladies, that could not endure our Zelotide, of which, the mot coniderable, was Cephia, ome important. Cae at Law, or ome contet at a meeting about their preeminence (for truly I was not certainly informed of it) had raied an enmity between their Families, whence this mortal hatred was tranmitted to our two fair ones. The quarrel had been decided for ome months before by their Friends, and Kindred, and omething like a reconciliation was made between them; but for all their peaceable friends could do in it, omething of the old grudge remained yet, which all the Town was very enible of Our Cavalier therefore, that was mighty great with this Troop of Ladies was by chance in the Garden, when Lycidas led in Zelotide, and eeing them alone by themelves, was infinitely overjoyed at o happy an occaion, to earch out what intelligence was betwixt them, which he hrowdly upected: To which
purpoe he hid himelf among the Trees of a blind Ally, not far from that in which our Gallant entertained his Zelotide, whence without being perceived, he heard the greatet part of the Ladies complaints, and dicovered, as faith he well might, that he was paionately in love with Lycidas, and that more then all this, he was divelih jealous of him. Never was any peron more atisfied at the bet news in the world, then he at this. He was already framing ten thouand malicious deignes againt the loving pair, and promied himelf as much divertiement, as he could wih from o pleaant an adventure. He was not long, e're he dicovered it to Cephia, and if my intelligence deceive me not, it was on the very next morning. The unlucky Lady is as hugely pleaed with it, and hoped, as well as the Cavalier, to draw no mall advantage from o welcome a dicovery.

Having laught their Bellies full, together, and conulted what they ought to do in this conjuncture; they at lat concluded, that if Zelotide was o jealous of her own Couin, he would be abominably jealous of another Lady, epecially if that Lady were her enemy; and that therefore, if they could perwade Lycidas to viit their company, Zelotide would even die with depite, but before her departure, he would be guilty of ome pretty extravagancies, which would give them matter enough to laugh at it.

After thee grave determinations, the Cavalier engaged to bring Lycidas to give her a viit, and he on her part very confidently promied
mied him, that uppoing he brought him thither, he hould be made to come again.

Thus were they plotting, Sir, againt the poor Zelotide, that never dreamed of thoe mieries they deigned her, whilt he poor Lady enjoyed all the happines he could wih for, for Lycidas forbore to ee Melite, and had performed all he was bound to, at leat, in her opinion he had. But faith, Sir, to tell you the plain truth, he was half a weary of Zelotides Tyranny, and without quetion, he had not remained faithful o long as he did, had not Fear more then Love perwaded him to't, for now he was no longer ignorant of her Fury and Jealouie, and feared them too, no les, then he loved and admired her Beauty.

lg.l: The weets of Love
He till deir'd to prove,

div.p: But then thoe weets of Love to him would be Inipid, when for them he lot his liberty.

He of the humour he then was, had rather enjoy the liberty to gaze on all the Ladies in the world, without any other advantage, then that of ubcribing himelf their ervant, then to be reduced to thoe hard terms of eeing but one, though he loved and favoured him, as if Heaven and Earth would come together. And it was this inclination of his, that rendred Zelotide's Empire o odious to him, but he could not well diingage himelf; and faith, though
he was a Soldier, I dare wear he durt not: He knew Madam Zelotide and her confounded humour well enough, to know what treatment he mut expect of her if he forook her; and it was not improbable, that her kindred that were very coniderable in the Town, would very much reent his ill uage of the Lady, hould the ecret ever be dicovered, as he was like enough to do it. So that he was engaged to viit no other Lady in the Town, and almot reolved too, and that as eriouly as one of his humour could, never to give her any more reaon to be jealous of him, But, faith, it was no hard matter to detroy his reolutions; and truly our Cavalier, though no incomparable Orator, had not much to do to perwade him to go ee the fair Cephia,

Lycidas knew very well the preent tate of the Town, and by conequence could not be ignorant of that averion Zelotide had for her, nor what his Mi's entiment would be of this viit; and truly this conideration made him for ome few minutes, reit the temptation, when the Gentleman perwaded him, but when he was omething urged to it, both becaue he was her neighbor, and thereupon at leat ingaged to viit her, and for ome other petty reaons, as inconiderable as the firt, he conented to it, hoping that Zelotide might never know of it,

Being now fully perwaded, the Cavalier leads him to ee Cephia; he was a pretty young gay Creature, o that any one of her many rare Qualities would be ufficient to have engaged a hardder
heart then Lycidas's; and telling you this, I need not tell you that our Gallant grew deperately in love with her, that is, as deperately in love as he could be. He preently forgot his jealous Lady, and doing as he ued to do, had not the patience to delay his amorous Declaration until the next viit.

lg.l: He had till ready made.
His vows his oaths, and all his am'rous Trade,
(Thoe pretty Engines to deceive a Maid)
Jut as ome quacking cheat
Doth till the ame to a yllable repeat,
And with hard words ten thouand times aid o're,
Still cheats the Rabble as he did before.
His Declaration was till the ame
To all he ever came
From the brisk Courtier to the City Dame
And alt'ring but a word or two
It till will do
Nor need he a new Speech indite.
Still, till the ame to th' black, to th' brown and white.

div.p: Cephia now had got him at the point he wihed, and therefore to keep him there, he received his addrees mot obligingly, and anwered his Declaration, with all the civility imaginable; o that when he left her, he was engaged as much as he could wih him, and was now fully reolved to viit her as often as poibly he could.

As oon as he was got home, he fell a conidering what a horrid trouble he hould be brought into, if Zelotide, hould chance to dicover his new engagement; but being very willing to flatter himelf, he thought, though he had but little reaon to do o; that Cephia living in a by-corner of the Town, and never peaking to Zelotide, the buines might very well be concealed from his troubleome jealous Lady.

And to effect his deign, he parted his viits betwixt his two Mitrees, with all the care imaginable; and truly his diligence was very uccesful. For Cephia and the ill-natured Cavalier, would not have his new paion talked of, till it was out of poibility to be detroyed; and that Zelotide might be the more enraged, when he knew how long Lycidas had been unfaithful to her. Our pretty jealous Creature therefore knew nothing of his viits for a week or two, but he had oberved omething however, that began to diquiet her; and that he might look to't in time, he reolved to peak to Lycidas of it, when next he aw him.

On that very day that he had taken this reolution, he failed not to wait upon her, and their dicoure very happily chancing to be about fidelity, he commended his, own to her with all the vehemence imaginable, and wore that trict obedience he had rendred her, ince he was pleaed to forbid him the company of Melite, was o uncommon, and admirable, that he was very much obliged to him for it: Yes, Sir, anwered he, I mut confes I cannot blame
you for viiting my Couin, but for Heavens ake take heed you give me not a more jut occaion to complain of you upon ome other account. I have perceived omething that makes me very much upect your unfaithfulnes; for Gods ake do not jutifie my upitions and let it not be true, that Lycidas affects Cephia You know I hate her mot mortally, and that I had rather you hould wait on all the Ladies in the Town, then that enemy of our Family. And know, Sir, it is not without reaon I tell you of her.

On Sunday you aluted her at Church with greater repect then I could have wihed, and he returned your reverence with an obliging Air, and a look o paionate, that it plainly witneed ome intelligence betwixt you.
On Munday I aw your Man and her Maid together, in o familiar a conference, that I fear the Mater and Mitris were concerned in it.

On Tueday I was informed, though not from you, Sir, you changed your Lodging near Cephia's, and that your Landlady had ometimes erved her, and was till very often with her. This Neighborhood, this Landlady, and this Familiarity between them, you mut needs grant is upicious.
On Wedneday you pardoned a Soldier that fled his Colours, at the Requet of the Huband of my Enemy, though you had refued before to pardon him, when all the Town entreated you.
On Thurday when her Coach was over-turned, you broke through the croud to help her, though I am confident you were not ignorant, that you would have very much obliged me, had you let her die there.

And yeterday, I was told that you took her Taylor and Shoomaker; and faith, Sir I mut tell you, people think very trangely of thee Taylors and Shoomakers, that work both for Men as well as Women; there are thoe will wear they meddle with omething ele beides their Trade; and making Shooes and Cloaths is not all they are employed in: the Taylor epecially, thoe gentile Mechanicks, that can with uch a dres, joyn Breeches and Peticoats.

So that there is not one day all this week, that I have not had jut reaon to upect you. For to compleat the week, this morning I am very credibly informed, that in company where you were, you commended Cephia before all the Ladies in the Town. And now, weet Sir, let me aume the confidence to demand of you, whither one can praie a Lady o extreamly, without knowing her, or know her without offending me; ince I hate her unmercifully, and it is the mot enible affront I can receive of any friend of mine, to viit her.

When Zelotide had ended her Bill of Grievances, Lycidas did all he could to pacify her. He proved to her that all her upitions were very lightly grounded, and at lat made no concience to wear to her mot Religiouly, that, he never went to ee that Lady, nor never would
while he breathed. Zelotide was willing to believe him, but all his Rhetorick could not abolutely perwade her, and undoubtedly your Royal Highnes will not blame her incredulity, which was at preent mot reaonable. The poor jealous Lady after a troubleome night, gave order next morning to her Lacquey, to go take a fit pot in a blind Allie before Cephias Gate, to ee without being dicovered, whether Lycidas entred there or no.

lg.l: The little fool might then have cur'd
Thoe tortures he endur'd
And by an inn'cent lie
Her ret, her peace procur'd
And ilenc'd her ditracting jealouie.
Thus diobedience might his faith expres;
He'd erv'd her better had he obey'd her les.

div.p:
She was now aur'dly her too zealous Lackquey, that he was abued, and-that her Lover viited her Enemy; he longed to ee him again-to punih him for his midemeanors. But Lycidas not coming all next day to wait upon her, eeing it was fair, and fit for a walk, he reolyed towards the evening to turn cout her elf, and go watch the unfaithful Lycidas; upon this deigne he takes onely her Lacquey with her, and under pretence of going to ee a Woman, that nurs'd a Child of hers, and that lived in the Suburbs; where he knew that Cephia and all her company commonly walked, he tood Sentinel in the Houe to ee whether
Lycidas were among them. But all her trouble, that he gave her elf, was to no purpoe, for Cephia being omething indipoed, went not out that evening, and Zelotide was now benighted, when he returned homewards. As he was going through the treet where Cephia lived, and was got hard by the Gate, he heard Lycidas his voice not above ix yards from her; whereupon he topped to hearken what he aid, and was not long e're he heard him peak to the Cavalier, and promied him to tay for him at Cephia's. Being now an Ear-witnes of his unfaithfulnes, he thought on nothing, but following the dictates of her Anger and Jealouie, he Commanded her Lacquey to retire, and making ue of the favour of the night, he entred the Gate without dicovery, and o got upon the Stair-cae where he reolved to expect Lycidas; Lycidas having left the Cavalier, entred very briskly, and never dreaming of the Ambucado that was laid for him.

lg.l: Spurr'd on by Love, away he run,
And up the Stairs he got as oon
In pite of night, as if he'd een the Sun.
Deire, weet weet deire led on the way
Who could to eek a Mitris, go atray?

div.p:
But your Royal Highnes may very well imagine how urprized he was, when he felt himelf topped, and perceived he was in the Arms of a Woman; he thought at firt it had been Cephia, who came out of roguery to frighten
him (for he never o much as thought of Zelotide) and hereupon cryed out; Fair Cephia, you thought to frighten me, and thought I hould not know you; but your bright Eies have betrayed you, and their light Madam, hath poiled your plot to keep your elf undicovered: and now faith, Madam, I mut have atisfaction for this malicious deigne upon me, and the place is o fit and proper for my revenge, that I never deerve the happineis, if I let lip o fair an opportunity.

lg.l: Had the cros Lady but conented to't,
He would have oon perform'd what e'r he pleas'd;
Had but the jealous Creature let him do't,
He had her Anger and her Rage,
Mot manfully awag'd.
Spite of her elf, he had her elf appeas'd.

div.p:
But he was trangely atonihed, when in tead of that Courteie, he expected, the unknown Lady cares'd him with all her natural weapons,; Tooth and Nail he was at it, and her Feet were not idle neither. For anger had o tranported Zelotide, that at firt he had lot the ue of her Speech, but faith Sir, he retained the natural faculty of biting, cratching, and kicking. Lycidas was never o handomely entertained before, and in the midt of his urprize, he could not imagine whence proceeded all this obliging Treatment; but at lat he came to be informed of it, by thoe reproaches that Zelotide, after he had got her peech again, mot bitterly porued
him with; Ingrateful Man, aid he, perfidious wretch, dot thou thus oberve thy Oaths, thy Vows, and Promies; yea, you wore to me with all the impudence in the world, that you would never viit Cephia, and yet I catch you here my elf in the night time, and in uch a condition too, that hows you are in no bad terms with her.

lg.l: And till puruing her fierce rage,
Which the poor Gentleman could ne'r awage,
Her Feet, her Nail, her Teeth again
Began to torm amain,
She bit, he cratch'd, he flung,
While till her Tongue
Such a damn'd peal rung,
That for its violence the torm could ne'r be long
O had he had a Ponyard in her hand
How he'd a tab'd the faithles Gentleman;
He from her rage mut needs have found his death,
Though he for grief next minute lot her breath.

div.p:
All that ever the poor Lycidas could do in this conjuncture, was to make ue of all the trength he had, to carry her away in his Arms, and bear her by plain force into the treet; for he very wiely conidered, that Cephia's Stair-cae was no very convenient place to make his reconciliation in with Zelotide, and that if this adventure came to be known, then might, God knows what come of it. But he could not carry her away o uddainly, but Cephia heard the
noie, though he knew not exactly what the matter was, and the noie ceaing on the uddain, he believed that ome of the Houhold had been playing the fool together.

At lat Lycidas having got Zelotide into the treet, and given her his hand to lead her home, he began to how how imprudently he had behaved her elf; how that if her extravagance had been known, he would have given a very ample ubject for Cephia and the malicious Cavalier to laugh at, nay, and all the Town too, and that hence-forward he ought to take a greater care of her Honour and Reputation. Take thou then a greater care of it, replyed the poor Lady weeping; Cruel Man! ince thou knowet to what tranports thy Love carries me, oughtet thou to expoe me to all occaions of them? and ought not you out of gratitude and acknowledgement, to ceae to viit that Woman, that I hate above all the world, and which you ought to hate too, had you any love or repect for Zelotide?

lg.l: Thus to fierce rage ucceeds oft tendernes,
And a wie Lover can make ue of this.

div.p:
And o did our Lycidas, who feeing his Zelotide omething pacified, hoped he might wholly pacify her; o that having walked along for ome time, and now brought her almot home, he deired her to wipe away her Tears, and to put her elf in order as well as he could let the Houe might take notice; And then he promied her, that as oon as he was got home, he
would jutify himelf better then he thought 'twas poible he could; nay, he engaged he would bring her uch reaons, as hould abolutely atisfy her; and as oon as they were got into the houe, both of them eating themelves on a Couch together, and out of all hearing, Lycidas poke either this, or omething like it.

I Mut confes, Madam, I promied you never to viit Cephia, nor was I ignorant of your averion for that Lady, nor how much I hould diingage you, hould I admit of any engagement with your enemy; yet after all this my frank confeion of thoe faults you charge me with, be pleaed but to conider how I committed the crime, and you will be enforced to confes it was not o great as you would pleae to make it. The firt viit I made Cephia, I was abolutely neceitated to. You remember, Madam, that day the Coach was overturned, I happened to be o nigh the place, that civility engaged me to uccor the Lady; and then it was, Madam, that I was contrained to lead her home; on the morrow he ent her Husband to return me thanks for my civility, o that I hould have been the meeret Clown in nature, had I not waited upon her. About two or three days after, I went to acquit my elf of this obligation, and there I met a company at Cards, where they would needs make me a Gameter; and then having lot all my Money, not to abue you, Madam, it was that onely conideration drew me thither, as Gameters mot commonly do all they can to ave themelves. It is true, Madam, I never made you acquainted with it, and I was fearful
it might dipleae you, hould you come to know of it; and I cannot deny neither, ince you will know all, that ometimes when I was at Cephia's, I never playd neither, but be pleaed to know then, it was becaue I found no convenient company; and you know very will, Madam, ince your Husbands return to Town, I cannot have the liberty to wait upon you o often as I could wih, o that not knowing whither to go, I have ometimes gone thither; this Houe of Cephia's is not far from my Lodging, o that I have pent ome hours there, more for cutom or convenience, then for any inclination: I have been there ometimes after dinner, but faith; Madam, it was becaue I knew not how to pend my time elewhere, and ometimes a cros humour of mine hath kept me there, only out of deign to vex the Lady and the Cavalier, for I aw my preence gave retraint to their company, o that, Madam, did you but know how I carry my elf there, hating Caphia as much as you can for the hear of you; you would be very well atisfied at thoe viits I render her: ometimes I compliment her, but it is after o mad a train, that neither he, nor I my elf undertand a word of it: and after all thee obliging fooleries for divertiement, I pick a quarrel with her, and rip up all her faults to her face; in a word, Madam, I treat her like a peron that you hate.

I believe, Sir, thee excues will not eem very plauible, and it is poible, too long too, to be poke to an impatient Lady without interruption: but Zelotide I can aure you, heard them mot attentively, and highly approved them for
the fear he conceived of loing Lycidas, and the joy he reented to ee him excue himelf, with o much ubmiion, after uch an adventure, when he might reaonably expect he would have broke with her, appeaed her intantly, nay and made her repent too of her rah proceedings: he promied therefore Lycidas to love him as much as ever, upon condition he would no more ee Cephia. Lycidas told her, he could not o oon leave off eeing her, let it might occaion ome trange reports in the Town, and make people upect them; but he aured her, the next time he played there, he would raie ome quarrel, that he might have ome pretence for his retreat thence. Zelotide was very well atisfied with his deign.

lg.l: So the two Lovers march'd along,
And o're and o're
They vow'd and wore
They never more
Would their true Love and weet contentment wrong.
The peace thus formally concluded was,
When Zelotide and Lycidas
The more to trengthen it, thought good
To Sign the Treaty with their Blood.
They now redoubled all their kindnees,
And their true love more firmly to expres;
Did with true Fleh and Blood,
What luty Lovers do, and whiners wih they cou'd.

div.p:
When Lycidas promied Zelotide to diingage himelfe from Cephia, he really intended it. But
he no ooner aw that lovely Lady, but he grew concious of his diability to perform his promies.

lg.l: For when he aw the pretty Dame again,
His Faith recoil'd,
His Loyalty was baely foil'd,
Nor could he any more his word maintain,
And if he aw her once, he mut again.

div.p: And beides all this, he had not yet obtained the fruition of his wihes, and a kis, and the like, had been all he had yet received of her, o that reolving not to loe all that trouble he had already ingaged in, he purued his viits; the jealous Lady was very well acquainted with them, but when ever he poke of them to Lycidas, he told her he was jut upon the point to leave her, and that he had not yet found any occaion to tart a quarrel, as he told her he would.

That plotting Fop the Cavalier did not yet know a word of what had pat upon the Staircae, o that he uffered a very coniderable los in it, for had he come to know o pleaant an adventure, that malice of his that was o natural to him, had drawn very fine advantages thence, and that talkative humour of his, would have been extreamly gratified in publihing the ecret with all the expedition imaginable. But though he mied of this, he hit upon one far better, and he was continually hammering omething to diturb the bet friends he had in the world, he lighted on a mot cured Intrigue that plagued
Lycidas and Zelotide no les, then it atisfied the Author and Cephia.

One evening, that was one of the mot erene and pleaant that ever had been een, and that invited all the Town to walk Abroad in o weet a eaon; all the handome Creatures in the Town, went abroad to take the Air in the Garden I told you of before. Lycidas led Zelotide thither too, where they had not taken above three or four turns, before the Cavalier and Cephia dicovered them, and thinking they had a mot happy opportunity to practice a divelih project of theirs, that they had been plotting for ome time before, they reolved to put it in practice. The Gentleman projector would needs manage it himelf, who meeting a Lacquey of a Friend of his, gave him inductions what he had to do, and to encourage him to perform his part with the greater willingnes, gave him omething: the Lacquey was very willing to erve him, and took the Letter that the Cavalier had provided before hand, and following the orders had been given him, he went to eek out Lycidas, and having found him without any great difficulty, he delivered him the Letter in Zelotide's company, and told him a Lady that he knew not, had commanded him to give him it. The young Rogue taid not long enough to be asked many quetions, but immediately diappeared (if I can properly ay one diappears in the night, when there is almot no appearing) The Letter produced mot effectually what it was deigned for. For Zelotide conidering how
it was delivered; upected ome new engagement, and thought Lycidas was got again at his infidelity.

lg.l: Now for ome Treaon Lycidas
Supected was.
On the leat ubject he
Reviv'd her Jealouie.
Whilt her curt humour did her oul inpire,
From the leat park, he'd trait advance a fire.
Her rage mut till oppoe what e'r withtood,
And what you would not have her ee, he wou'd.

div.p:
It was for this reaon that he preently natched the Letter out of Lycidas's hands, and was fully reolved to read it: the two pies that followed them at ome ditance, and were a preparing themelves to laugh their guts out, were not at all deceived in their expectation. They heard Zelotide very urgent with Lycidas to go out of the Garden, to ee for a Light to read the Letter, while that poor Lover was diwading her to no purpoe.
