For though he was wholly ignorant whence the Billet came, he was fearful there might be omething in it, that her jealouie might make ome ill interpretation of, and for this reaon he did all he could to keep her in the Garden, and ued all the wit he was mater of to get the Letter from her. But his endeavors proved uccesles, and Zelotide pying a Light in the Gardeners, he forced Lycidas thither with her. The poor Gentleman o hung an Are, you might eaily perceive, with what regret he went forward,
and the jealous Lady trooped along with uch precipitation, that by her pace you might ee her impatience. Cephia and the Cavalier followed them undicovered, and took a very convenient pot under a little blind window of a ground-Chamber, whence they might eaily ee without dicovery, and hear through the Glas all that paed between the Lovers. The impatient Creature was no ooner got nigh a Lamp, that gave light to all the little houe, but he examined the Seal of the Letter, but not knowing it he at lat opened it, but faith, drew as little atisfaction from that, as he had from the Seal before; he found nothing there but trange conjuring kind of Characters, that he undertood not one tittle of; and it is very probable no body ele. It is impoible to tell you what an exces of grief and depite, he reented at o trange a rencounter. She was preently perwaded that thee were ome Cyphers or other that Lycidas undertood, and that without quetion, this Billet invited him to ome Aignation with ome new Mitris of his. Hereupon he begs of him, he threatens him, he perecutes him to dicover this Mytery. But the Divel was in him if he did, for he undertood no more of it, then he did, and all he could do, was to wear he could not devie the meaning of it, that without doubt the Lacquey and mitaken him for ome body ele, and delivered the Letter to a fale peron. All this was true, he told her, for the Cavalier had cribled over the Paper with thoe Arabian Pothooks, onely to ditract the poor Zelotide, and expoe
her ridiculous jealouie and extravagance: But Lycydas might wear long enough before he believed him; he till reted perwaded he was betrayed again by the unfaithful Lycidas, and took this Letter for an undoubted proof of it. Being grown now almot deperate, and never hoping to get the ecret out of Lycidas, he makes ue of her lat effects of Goodnes, of Rage, and all the Eloquence they had inpired her with.

lg.l: Nay my dear Lycidas I prethee tell.
I'faith you mut, and all hall trait be well,
I'le gently pardon my dear Infidel.
Nay I'le commend thee for thy ecreie,
Excuing what I did not ee.
Come with that fear dipence
And make me one of your Intelligence.
And ince my weaker Beauty could not be
Pow'rful enough to chain your liberty
Come, come, this pretty victres pray let's ee.
Though I the torments of a Rival prove,
Yet I'le be worn, lle not diturb your Love.
I'le think ome handomer
You did to me prefer,
I'le think her charms might well your Loyalty,
Detroy, and make my ervant fale to me.

div.p: But eeing he'd prevail'd nothing by her entreaties he decended to her Rage and Fury again, which it will be extreamly difficult to expres, to your Royal Highnes.

lg.l: Cruel inhumane Man he aid,
And wilt thou till conceal thy guilty Love?
That guilty Love that hath thy faith betray'd,
And makes poor Zelotide uch pains to prove?
She top'd awhile, and then her rage diplaid.
Yes, I will know that wicked Jilt
I will, bae Man, and when I hall
Have found her out, he in thy ight hall fall,
And expiate both thine and her own guilt.
My Rival by this hand hall dy,
Yes, Sir, 'tis Jutice, and not Cruelty.
Nor care I what the graver world may cry.
Let 'em condemn my Rage, or jutify;
Credit's a thing remote, when injur'd Love is by.

div.p: If your Royal Highnes could poibly be urpried at any thing, it would without doubt, to ee a Woman make Veres thus extempore; But if that opinion be true that tells us, that Poetry hath omething of Enthuiame and Fury in it, you mut needs confes, Sir, that Zelotide was in a mot incomparable vein Poetical.

Lycidas was now infinitely troubled with her Pray'rs and her Menaces; But it was out of his pow'r to atisfy her, and unfold a mitery, that he himelf was utterly ignorant of. And now Zelotide eeing neither her p • ay'rs nor her threats could force the ecret from him, very happily thought upon a tratagem, that mut of neceity convince him. She was confident, that he had received more Letters then this one, from his new Mitris, and that if he earched him immediately
upon the pot, he hould find ome other tokens of his perfidie about him. Having abued her elf into this opinion, he mut earch his pockets, where he found a great company of Letters that he received from his friends and kindred; he had the patience to open all, one after another, and finding there ome few of 'em of a Womans hand, he read them over and over, and unhappily meeting with omething in them that he did not well undertand, he preently concluded they came from her unknown Rival; for though Lycidas was Treated as a Couin or Brother in them, he aid, that was only out of confederacy to hide their deceit. In fine, having read over five or ix of them, and dicovered nothing coniderable, he went to open another; but Lycidas eeing by the Supercription, that it came from his Siter, about ome buines that concerned his Family, which for many coniderations he was engaged to conceal; he pulled it from her, and told her that he could not poibly let her read that, and immediately tore it in pieces. Your Royal Highnes may eaily imagine that there needed no more to perwade her that this Letter came from her Rival, and might have dicovered all the ecret to her.

lg.l: Seeing him tear the Letter, up he flew,
She tore his Face and Hair,
Or by his Hair along the Lover drew,
Such were the dictates of her fell dipair.
And could her Nails have reach'd his Heart,
(Where her fair eies had often play'd their part.
And tamp'd her Image with o weet an Art)
She would his Heart have torn in pieces too,
And pul'd her Image thence,
She with that los could eaily dipence,
Could he but give the faithles Man his due,
And he that firt the fierce Megera drew
Might very well have took her Image hence.

div.p: But the good honet Gardener, which had never read of Megera, nor perhaps heard of her, took her for ome Woman bit by a mad Dog, and thereupon armed himelf with all his Utenils, his Bill and his Knife, &c. that he might upon occaion turn Spaniard, and fight with Sword and Dagger, and I cannot tell what beides, let he hould do him a michief. Cephia and the Cavalier were not altogether o fearful; all the pain they were in, at leat the mot coniderable, was to forbear laughing out, let they hould be dicovered.

All that the poor Gallant, (I think I may jutly call him o in this adventure) could do after his mad Treatment, to fly his mad Mitris, (and faith I believe he did it as heartily as ever he ought her before,) and ave his Honour in the ight of the Gardener and his Wife, who as he thought, were the only pectators of the Tragedy, was to anwer her fury with railery, and get out of her hands as oon as he could; o that pying ome Kinmen of Zelotide's a walking in the
Garden, and as good fortune would have it, omething near the Gardeners, he went out very briskly, having firt taken the Letters from the pretty fretful Lady, and entreated them to accompany Zelotide home, for he was engaged to leave her there, to quell ome diorder that had happened among the Soldiers of his Company. He was glad he got off o, and was now fully resolved never more to expoe himelf to her capricious extravagancies.

Zelotyde hearing how handomely he had made out the tory to her friends, had ome comfort to ee with what prudence and dicretion he had excued her, and made ue of the ame pretence, as he had done. Her credulous Kinmen were eaily abued thus, but Cephia and her Gentleman, that had een what had pat at the full length, knew the truth of all but too well for her repoe and reputation. They laughed to ome purpoe, you need not doubt it, but the unconcionable Creatures were not content to laugh among themelves, they mut needs publih it too, and communicate the ucces of their Intrigue. And your R. H. need not wonder at it.

lg.l: For tifled Joy does to a torment turn,
And what was made too warm, begins to burn.
Its force is prightly, quick, and vigorous,
And if you keep it in, more active grows,
But then its force one Heart can ne'r contain;
Dipere thy Joy, and 'twill return with gain.
This pretty contradiction pleaures have,
For till their Joys encreas'd, the more they gave

div.p: And it eems the Cavalier was very certain of this, for he had rather have lot the better half of Blood, then the pleaure to publih o pleaant a tory; on the morrow therefore (o that it eems, the Cavalier was omething mannerly not to call up his friends out of Bed at that time of night to tell it them) it was Town-talk, and many a dull Droll had bin pat upon it. And now the Cavalier was as happy as he could wih to be; oh how he hug'd himelf, and it is very probable took himelf for the greatet wit of the Age, after o brave an Intrigue, o gallantly managed? o that you may eaily imagine he told it to all he met with, what interet he had in it, how it was he that wrote the Letter, and took care to ee it delivered. He poke beides this, all the finet things he could upon that ubject, and rallyed upon it after a horrible rate, where ever he could find any that had the patience to hear him. Lycidas was told of it that very day, and eeing what bad effects this raillery might produce, that it was too bitter for a friend; and beides, he was engaged in Honour to tetify by ome gallant action, that he had not pread the report about, but ome body ele, he ought out the Cavalier, and deiring to be informed of the flying report that came from him, he could get no other atisfaction from him, but ome new abues; o that bidding him draw immediately, before they could be parted, he wounded him in the Arm in two everal places.

lg.l: And thus our petty Satyrits came off
After the pleaure of a coff,
When on their heads their Railleries till fall,
And as they tal'kd, o now they uffer all:
They find themelves undone,
Becaue they laugh'd too oon:
They damn their Drollery
And now too late they ee,
When all the danger's pat
'Tis then the happines to laugh at lat.

div.p:
The combat happening to be in a publick place, it could not be of any long continuance. The Combatants were preently parted, but the news of their quarrel being uddainly dipered, their friends immediately made thither, and ranked themelves on one ide and the other. The Cavalier had many very coniderable Kinmen in Town. But Lycidas was in the head of a Regiment, o that they could not eaily make aault upon him. Their common friends eeing that the Cavaliers wounds were not dangerous, and the tir that the quarrel had raied among the people, might break out into ome diorders, reolved to take order betimes about it. Cephias Gentleman, the Man I mean that he call'd Huband, was one of the mot active among them, to bring the Combatants to ome agreement; for having learned that his Lady was concerned in the candalous report, he judged himelf engaged to ilence it, with all the expedition he could. To which purpoe he went with ome
friends of his to the principal Officers of the Regiment, who were very glad to ee themelves prevented in treating for a pacification; and to requite his civility, they agreed that the peace hould be concluded at his Houe. The two fighters were led thither, and there they embraced one another, after ome petty atisfactions adjudged to Lycidas, which my Intelligence did not acquaint me with, and which, it is no matter whither your Royal Highnes know or no, ince they are not material to the tory.

Zelotide preently heard of the quarrel, but was not acquainted with the caue of it, for no body was o imprudent and uncivil as to acquaint her or her Husband with that raillery that had pat all the Town through upon the Garden-adventure. So that the jealous Creature not knowing what Lycidas and the Cavalier fought about, gueed at the caue of the quarrel, as a jealous Lady hould do, She believed that the Cavalier that had erved Cephia a long time before, could not endure her engagement with Lycidas.

lg.l: For Rivals, if they once but chance to meet
With odd carees do each other greet,
Honour and Love Command them to fight on,
He for the Girl the Honour has to dye,
And he lives till the fair one to enjoy,
For one can ne'r be well, till th' other's gone.

div.p:
This opinion of hers very much augmented her jealouie, if it was any longer capable of degrees;
and the poor Lady for five or ix days, was plagued wore then ever. For ince the adventure of the Letter, Lycidas had never waited on her, o that he could not have the pleaure to tell him of his infidelity, nor the atisfaction he deired, to know the certainty of her upitions he was now throughly perwaded, that Lycidas had quite deerted her, to viit Cephia with the greater convenience, that her Rival triumphed over her and her Beauty, and that it was probable they were diverting themelves with her extravagance.

lg.l: Thee thoughts of hers o ditracted her,
That when her fury grew les violent,
She of her jealouie would oft repent,
And thinking on thoe mieries,
Thoe briny Tears and bitter Sighs,
Her humour did o fruitfully create.
Her Rage, her Fury, he her elf would hate.
But then conidering
With what high reaon he had jealous been,
What reaon then he had
To Storm, to Rage, to bid her Soul run mad;
Her jealouie he jutify'd,
And wore he'd till be jealous, though he dy'd
Of her repentance he repented too,
All was unjut but what her Fury prompted to.

div.p:
She had an hundred different reolutions in an intant, and ome of them abolutely detructive of all the ret, but at lat having conulted her
own oul, he reolved to do her uttermot to retrieve her Lycidas.

lg.l: She hop'd he till might think her fair,
Her Eyes were till as charming as they were,
When they firt conquer'd him,
And did o lovely eem.
And if he mut depair,
Her former Conquets ever to repair,
She judg'd it better till
To ee him, though an Infidel,
Then ne'r to ee the Man he lov'd o well.

div.p:
This reolution eemed o plauible to her, that he preerved it for ome days, and while he was in this mind, he very happily met an Officer of the Regiment, that he had ome little knowledge of, and that was a very intimate friend of our Lycidas's, and if I am not very much mitaken, he met him as he was coming out of the Church one day. The Officer, being very obliging to the Ladies, as all Lycidas's his Chronies mut needs be, offered her his ervice to hand her to her Coach, which he very willingly accepted, becaue he imagined, he might learn of him the ground of the quarrel; and truly, though my Author mentions it hot, I can eaily be perwaded, it was as well to get a new ervant, as to enquire after the old one. The Officer was extreamly urpried to ee her ignorant of what all the Town talked of, and wherein he had o particular a concern, and could not believe but that it was only a piece of her Countenance, to
endeavour to perwade him that he was not the caue of it. But he poke to him o eriouly, and o earnetly intreated him to inform her, that at lat he was perwaded to it, both to erve the Lady, and do Lycidas a kindnes: He aured her therefore, that the Garden-adventure was known all the Town over; that Cephia and the Cavalier had divulged it, having firt been the eye-witnees of it in the Garden; that the Cavalier was Author of that Letter that had made all that diturbance, and that talking of it in all company he came into, Lycidas came to hear of it, and judging himelf in Honour obliged to demand reaon for the injury; and Duel a peron that had expoed that Lady that he mot paionately affected, to the laughtter and abuive raillery of all the Town he wounded the Cavalier, though not dangerouly, and the buines was taken up at Madam Cephia's, becaue her Husband had very much concerned himelf in their agreement.

Though this Relation very much afflicted Zelotide, when he heard how her extravagancies were laughed at, and what an ill opinion the Town might jutly conceive of her Vertue, yet he could not chue in the midt of all her orrows, but reent the greatet joy conceivable.

lg.l: She lov'd her Honour ne'r the wore for this,
Her Fame and Credit he did till prefer
To life, and what was ele more dear
Yet Love mut bear down all, what e'r it is.
Her kind eteem of both of them was great,
Great as eteem divided well could be,
But if the one of them mut needs retreat,
Poor Honour then that one mut be.
Love forc'd her to't with uch a weet neceity
That what e'r Honour urg'd in his defence,
Was foolery,
Scarce Sence.
Thus that he might her Love more truly prove,
She acrific'd her Honour to her Love.

div.p:
So that, Sir, you may eaily imagine that Zelotide was not extreamly troubled, and that he could admit of ome Conolation in the midt of her afflictions; for though he had lot her reputation, he was more concerned at the los of her Lover, whom now he hoped he might recover. She could now no longer preerve her anger againt Lycidas, ince he found her upitions of him were unjut, and he was more innocent than he imagined, and had behaved himelf like a Man of Honour in maintaining the interets of his Mitris with uch vigor, againt the malice of a Rival, and the raillery of an Enemy. And then he immediately was plotting how to revenge her elf on Cephia and the Cavalier, but he thought it now more convenient to think of Love than Revenge, and by all means to recall her Lycidas. She would not let lip o happy an opportunity, but humbly thank'd the Courteous Officer for the trouble he was pleaed to give himelf in acquainting her with the caue, and full relation of the quarrel;
again auring him, that till that moment he had been kept in ignorance of what o much concerned her; he told him, he acknowledged her elf infinitely obliged to Lycidas for the defence of her Honour, and having now found by his dicoure, that the Officer was Lycidas's Confident, and acquainted with all his ecrets, he very ingeniouly confeed to him, that vehement inclination, he had for his friend, and having by this obliging confidence drawn him into her Interet; he avow'd to him, that Lycidas had never een her ince the adventure in the Garden; that he was intollerably troubled at it, and that he would oblige her eternally, would he bring his friend along with him to honour her with a viit; that the chief reaon why he longed to ee him, was to beg his pardon for her unjut upitions of him, and expres her gratitude for the zeal he ued in her ervice.

This civil obliging Officer promied her all ee deired of him, and o left her, with a firm reolution to oblige Lycidas to wait upon her as much as formerly. The Lady had mov'd him with her pretty-taking converation, and her Wit and Beauty pleaed him o much, and he was o wholly amiable in his Eies, that he concluded he deerv'd to be erved with all the contancy in the world; that any Man of Honour or Concience ought to ret atisfied with uch a happines, and that his friend was too too blame for his infidelity to o incomparable a Lady; and truly it eems he really thought o, for he kept his word mot exactly; he told Lycidas of
all the dicoure he had with Zelotide, and proved to him, that he was engaged to wait upon her, that he ought to take thoe extrvagant effects of her jealouie for the marks of an incomparable affection, and that if Love could not induce him to ee her, yet fear might perwade him to't, for what might he not with jutice apprehend from a Lady as mad and deperate, as amorous.

p.U: ince his Quarrel with the Cavalier, had not een Zelotide indeed, but then neither had he een Cephia, having learned that he was an accomplice of his enemy; and o at that time his Love lay fallow, and without employment. For, Sir, I cannot jutly count thoe for viits, that he made then (for it eems by my intelligence, he was with ome more of the Females of the Town then two, though I have not learned their names nor quality) becaue he could not loe his liberty to any of the Ladies. But his humour would not permit him to live long thus.

lg.l: Unhappy he
Should he for two whole days without a Mitris be
Two uch whole days to him might well appear
More then a thouand year.
Ceation from his Love made eem
Each minute a whole age to him.
That muty ret to him appear'd more rude,
Then all the Lovers ervitude,
With all its Gall, and bitternes imbru'd.
Trouble he lov'd and doated on, while he
Could not be quiet in tranquillity,
He a true Soldier
Without the War
Would quickly broken be.

div.p: Beides, Sir, he could not be out with his Mitris for above eight days for the heart of him; and however they had plagued him, he forgot all their cruelties in a very hort time. So that there needed not much perwaion to draw him to Madam Zelotide's, His careful friend led him thither on the morrow, and knowing very well that when a pair of Lovers is once met, they, agree among themelves a great deal better, then they would by the mediation of a third peron, he left them either to be honet together, or do what they would; and they poor ouls were o well employed, that they never aw their common friend neak away from them.

lg.l: And though at firt they both diembled well,And faith here I think the Poet is in as bad a humour as his Lover.
She peronated the cruel,
And he as urly was as none can tell,
But he that wrote Squire Witherington's Knell;
He left Love to be judg'd of their quarrel.

div.p: This little upreme Judge knows his Art at well, as can be and draws coniderable advantages from uch diorders, and thoe which pretend to have a familiar acquaintance with him, aure us,

lg.l: That he exacts his Fee
With all the vigor of another Judge,
Which if the urly Lovers grudge
Immediately to atisfy,
The cured Villain leads him many a trudge.
But if they do, or at leat counterfeit,
All that they can to pay the debt,
If they talk nonence, play the fool
Sufficiently, and love by rule
He gives o kind a entence then
Both for the Ladies and the Men,
They both go atisfy'd away,
Though both are cat, both eem to win the day.

div.p: Our two Lovers, for now I think I may afely call them o, recompened him for all the care he took, to bring them to an agreement, with new acknowledgements, and new tetimonies of their ubmiion. And, as he is indeed a very pretty Arbitrator, and works our reconciliations, with the handomet addres imaginable;

lg.l: He brought the matter then about o well,
And did o neatly make them both agree,
With his weet Art, and pretty indutry
That the mot curious could not tell,
Who the mot willing was, the Man or he,
Both kis'd, both bluh'd, and bluhing aid;
In vain they have our Love betray'd.
Thus we redeem our fond delay,
And pull back yeterday.
Our melting kies,
And am'rous blis's
May teach the World there's no uch joy as this's:
Thus without wronging either,
The little Rogue pleas'd both, and injur'd neither
That's thus, he brought them both together,

div.p: Zelotide was never more atisfied ince he breathed, and Lycidas was never more contented; Zelotide was ravihed to find by the effect of her Garden-Adventure, that her ervant was more innocent then he thought he was; and that that happy unhappy adventure, had made him renounce her Rival too. Lycidas was no les atisfied at this conjuncture, that proved him a mot contant Inamorato, when if one might have earched his heart for him, he would have found him otherwie, and that furnihed him with freh means to deceive the poor Zelotide. They being thus equally overjoyed, the two Lovers, at lat parted, and reolved to meet as often as they poibly could.

While the two Lovers were thus happy to exces the fair Cephia mut not be forgotten, who as brisk as he was, began to be troubled at Lycidas's abence; he now began to perceive that her laughing had cot her dear, and that her raillery had made her loe a man that he loved great deal more then he thought he did, before he left her. She now repented of her Intrigues, and her deignes upon Zelotide, though he hated her more now then ever, ince they mut all fall upon her. She heard of Lycidas and her Rivals agreement, and thereupon redoubled her Hate of Zelotide, and Love of Lycidas. While the Cavalier had entertained her with his fooleries, laughing, and diverting her elf at the expence of her Rival, was all her employment, but now he thought on omething ele.

lg.l: That he reflected on her Love,
That he did never, as he ought, improve,
She cal'd her elf an innocent,
A fool that o oppos'd her weet intent,
And found that Zelotide,
Though he her prightly paion did not hide,
Was yet the wier of the two,
While he enjoy'd, what he but wih'd to do.
Thoe pleaures that he might have had,
When her bad conduct all her joys betray'd.
Did now torment her oul,
Which preent griefs and her lot joys controul.
And now her Love too late had made her ee,
That Lycidas,
(And then he call'd her elf an As)
That Man of Men, that lovely he,
Was fit for omething ele then Raillery,

div.p:
She was reolved to retrieve her Gallant, but here was the Divel on it, he could not devie how to effect her wihes, and recall her injur'd Lover. The, Cavalier, after their quarrel was no fit peron for uch a meage, and Lycidas had left his Landlady that had formerly been her ervant, o that every thing ran contrary to this unfortunate fair one. But, Sir, meer chance obliged her with the happiet opportunity he could have wihed, and that it was impoible he hould ever have thought on. She very happily met Lycidas at one of her Couins, that he went to viit; and this Couin, as good luck would have it, had got a Gentleman with her, that he had no averion for, o that leaving
Lycidas to entertain Cephia, he talked in private with this peron, for truly, Sir, I have not learned hit quality; Lycidas now very prettily engaged without the leat deign of his, to talk with Madam Cephia, he began his dicoure with reproaches; but the Lady made o many excues, and proteted o unfeignedly, and with o great a tendernes, that he was extreamly orry for what was pat, that the eaie Lycidas was touched with her ubmiion. And truly who could deny o ditreed a Beauty any thing? certainly Lycidas could not eaily do it. Inenibility, I dare be worn for him, was none of his crime.

lg.l: When any Mis of his
Had by ome bae devie
(None e'r diplea'd him with their cruelties)
Anger'd the injur'd Lover,
And in his Air did his jut rage dicover.
She might her pardon eaily procure,
Poor Lycidas could ne'r endure,
(Ladies you'l praie his pity ure)
Not to give pardon and himelf unto her.
When his reentments rag'd as high,
As injuries could make 'em flie.
He the offence could eaily forgive,
And let th' offender in his boome live.
Though by malicious ubtilty
He by the pretty Sex hould cheated be,
He'd till retain his clemency,
And might the Judgement be referr'd to him,
No witty Beauty, would long guilty eem.

div.p:
One cannot therefore wonder if thee ubmiive and charming excues of Cephia's did not very enibly move our Lycidas. Your Royal Highes will undoubtedly avow, that any one ele, far more inenible, and obdurate then our Gentleman was, would be extreamly touched with them; if you pleae to conider, with how taking an Air our pretty Criminal uttered them. Nay, he purued her ubmiion till and told him, that if by any fault of another nature, he could expiate her pat one, he was ready to engage in it, and prefer his Love to her Innocence; and that in a word, he would mot willingly procure his pardon at the expence of what he held mot dear in the world. The cunning Lady managed her buines rood incomparably, for the pacified Lycidas founded his happines upon her promies, and truly his hopes did not abue him; for after ome mall tay there, he led Cephia home again, where the peace was concluded to the great contentment of both parties. After this formality was once over, they agreed upon certain rules for their living together in better intelligence, and managing their pleaures for the future with prudence, the longer to continue them: Then they fell a talking of poor Zelotide, and her extravagant jealouie; but Lycidas being very unwilling to clah with her any more, told Cephia very ingeniouly, that he mut needs wait on her till; but he aured her, it hould be only out of policy, to avoid any new diorders, that her mad Love and Jealouie might produce. It was not long before Zelotide was informed
of their reconciliation, and of thoe viits the Gentleman made Cephia after their agreement; but Lycidas excued himelf very plauibly to her, and told her it was very difficult for him not to ee Cephia ometimes, ince all the Gameters continually met there, and all the piritual and ingenious perons of the Town made her Houe their Rendezvous; and then he wore he had no private acquaintance with her, and never aw her but in company; and thus the pretty Gentleman deceived the Ladies.

Now, Sir, You ee all is quiet, the Cavalier and the two Rival Ladies agree very well with our Gallant; but damned ill luck mut raie up a new diorder among them, and diturb their tranquility as much as formerly.

A Conin of Zelotides, we called her Cleonice in the beginning of this Hitory, was to marry one of her Siters (but truly, Sir, I could never learn what hey called her, though I ued all poible means to find it out) to a very near kinman of Cephia's (but faith, I cannot tell who he was neither.) Being the Wedding was to be publick, and very magnificent (whence I gather it was no Wetminter one, though perhaps the couple corned to have more honety then our Englih fools that are to be married at the place aforeaid) the Gallant (for yet I think I may call him o before he's brought to the Altar to acrifice his liberty, and debauch his Mitris into that dull and inignificant thing commonly called a Wife) for his part invited Cephia
and her Gentleman; and the Lady-Bride invited her friends thither, and among the ret, Zelotide and the thing he called Husband. Thee two Families, as I told you before, for all that feigned reconciliation, hated each other till mot mortally, but they concealed their enmity; they faintly aluted, one another when they chanced to meet, and when ill fortune brought them into company together, they were civilly complaiant, jut as we are to trangers commonly, o that they could not handomely refue their invitation, though they knew before hand who they mut expect to meet there. The Gentleman that was deigned for the Groom had been an Officer in Lycidas's Regiment, and had been for ome time an intimate friend of his; o that Lycidas was alo invited. The Feat was to be kept at a Villa of Cleonice's, about two miles out of Town. They all kept their Aignation very exactly; and Lycidas that came omething later then the ret was in the greatet trouble in the world to meet his two Mitrees both together in the ame company.

lg.l: Now Lycidas mut neds confes
That Happines
Has its exces,
And can to miery degenerate.
Thus plagu'd by two uch loving Mitrees
He wih'd their favour les,
Their Love diturbs him more then would their hate
Now he mut part his Favours too,
And his kind Graces jutly hare;
What hould the poor ditracted Lover do?
They both are witty, weet, and fair,
Sweet as when gentle Zephyrs Fan the Air,
That does unto ome Flowry Vale repair.
Brought to this ad ditres
Both how to leave and chue a Mitres,
He all their charms look'd o're
And found them both as charming as before.
What hall I do? he cry'd,
Can I thoe Lips and prightly Eies forake,
That would of Iove again a Satyr make,
Or force him o me new hape to take?
No, no, I can't leave either,
Nor can I my true Love divide.
Then I mud keep & love them both together.
While thus confounded his poor foul remains,
Now on his Zelotide he cats a glance,
And thence he did his love the more advance,
While he new Beauties py'd, and charms by chance,
That loaded him with more of th' Lovers Chains.
But when he look'd on his Cephia, then
His Love for her return'd agen.
While thus in ditracion he lay
Now leaning this, now th' other way,
Now the weet Girl, now th' jealous bore the way,
At lat hit Fetters he would needs retain,
And contant unto both remain;
But now at preent he mut ee
How to divert his miery;
And leat he hould dipleae either,
Reolv'd at preent to chue neither.

div.p:
So that he reolved that I may tell it your Royal Highnes in Proe as well as Vere, for that day to renounce both his Mitrees, and apply himelf to Madam Cleonice. Being he was the Mitres of the houe, and he had ome acquaintance with her ever ince he firt aw Zelotide, and no body ever upected him of any particular acquaintance with her, he thought he had taken the les dangerous reolution, and that by this happy means he might keep his Favour with both his Ladies. And truly the reasonable Cephia was contented to ee him betow his love any where ele but on Zelotide, and reckoned her elf infinitely engaged to him; but Zelotide was not of o tame a humour, he could not endure that her ervant hould cares any body beides her dear elf; and though he was overjoyed to ee that Lycidas did not o much as look upon Cephias; he was not atisfied with that, but would have had him cat an Eye on no body ele: but her prudence in this conjuncture, matered her oul, and concealed her reentments, o that by her actions none could judge of her inward motions, though he uffered all the torments that Rage and Jealouie could inflict, while our Lycidas at the Ball, at the Banquet, or where ever he was, was always with Madam Cleonice, and carried himelf o dicreetly, that one would have worn
he had not the leat inclination for Zelotide or Cephia,

Lycidas came off thus a day and for ome part of the night, till the Lady was brought whither he would be, to her Husbands embraces (for hang it, now that dull name mut be ued) where we hall leave them between the Sheets to their pleaures, (for, for the firt night they will be omething atisfied with one another ure, or ele they never will) and ee what the ret do, for you may gues at the married couples employment. Cleonice was now engaged to leave the company to go and give order for omething about the houe, and Lycidas, though he was very unwilling to part with her, was at lat forced to leave her; o that now he was at a los how to carry himelf The Ladies were at play in two everal companies, whereof Cephia was of the one, and Zelotide of the other. So that for fear of dipleaing either of his Mitries, he would not trike in there: and the Men were as hot a fudling as can be imagined, and the greater part of them even dead drunk, with a pretty kind of Wine they had got, that charm'd them o weetly, that they could have been content to have died over again, might they have o agreeable an Executioner. Lycidas was engaged there for ome time, but taied not long among them; for this port dipleaed him wore then the former, o that at lat he thought it bet to leave the company, and retire into ome dark chamber, without peaking a Syllable, let he might be diwaded
from his reolution. He was no ooner got where he intended, and laid himelf upon a Bed, that very happily he light upon in the dark, but finding himelf exceive weary with Dancing, he compoed himelf to take a nap, where he fell aleep very oundly, with his Cloaths on, and had lain ruff all night, had not a very pleaant adventure raied him: He had not been aleep much above an hour (it is poible it might be an hour and half quarter) when he felt omething pull him by the Arm, and he was not well awake, when by ome careing, and amorous kind of injuries, he perceived Zelotides voice; the prudent Gentleman foreeeing what inconveniences might hence arie, if he was caught with him in the dark, told her very civilly, he expoed her elf to too great a danger; that ome ervant might eaily dicover them together, and that the preervation of her Honour engaged her to leave him immediately, and avoid the dipleaure that he mut of neceity reent, if any one hould ple them together.

Any other Lover les prudent then Lycidas, would not have troubled himelf to mind his Mitris of her Duty in o happy an occaion; but, Sir, I am engaged to avow it to your Royal Highnes, for I know Lycidas to be naturally a very prudent peron, and one that loves to lay his Love-Intrigues as ure as can be.

But how gravely oever he preached to the Lady, it was ail to no purpoe: Zelotide told
him that he had jut left play, and had left all the company mighty eager at it; that all their Husbands and their Servants were half drunk; that he thinking to find him there by himelf, had toln up to him very ecretly; that no body would mind her abence, or if they did, would think he was gone to Bed; o that he might without the leat danger enjoy his weet company for ome few moments.

lg.l: Forgetting then his danger, up he drew,
And on his Prey he flew;
Now his dull prudence he did oon reject,
And nothing but hit Love repect,
His Love, his gameom Love he thought upon;
Widom & Prudence with their gang begone,
To phlegmatick Philoophers retire,
That tell you of content, & dream of nothing higher.
Lovers mut mount; they'r all, they'r all a fire,
What aucy danger dare his joys molet?
And pull the Lover from his Ladies Breat,
While he lies there 'twould impious be,
To think of ought but Loves felicity
And its fair Source, his lovely he,
As in a Church 'twould impious be,
To think of ought beides the Deity.

div.p:
The Lady when he aw her Gallant full perwaded, took her place very obligingly on the Bed-ide next the Wall, and begun a very pleaant entertainment with the too too happy Lycides, whereat both parties were very well atisfied,
and I am confident, would never have been tired before morning, had not an unlucky accident intervened. The Lady had not long enjoyed what he deired, before he heard, as well as Lycidas, ome noie upon the Stairs. This uddain troubleome noie obliged them to keep ilence, and hearken what the matter was; immediately after they heard their Chamber door open, and ome body come into them. Your Royal Highnes may very well imagine what a condition this unexpected rencounter put our two Lovers in, they were afraid of all the world, and the mallet fortune they could hope for, was to be found together with Zelotides good Husband. This, exceive fear of theirs had rendred them immoveable, and o they continued till Lycidas felt ome thing very gently pull him by the Hair. He tirred not for all that, but norted mot couragiouly, to perwade the unknown Creature, if he could, that he was ound aleep; but whoever the incognito was, it pulled him o trangely, that he could not any longer peronate the leeper? beides ome pretty tender dicoures, and ome few claps of the cheeks, had now almot dicovered the peron; and thoe pretty weet carees made him wear it was Cephia: and faith he was the very peron that diturbed the dark entertainment, who having left off play, and miing Lycidas, he looked for him among the Debauche's, but not finding him there neither, he came to look for him in this very chamber; Zelotide that was got on the other ide of the Bed, durt not o much as breath with
freedom, for fear he hould be dicovered, but litened very attentively, and eaily knew Cephia by here voice, and eeing with what familiarity he careed her Servant, did but too plainly ee their engagement; whereupon he grew tark mad with Lycidas, and no les with Cephia, her depire crack'd her heart-trings; and that which very enibly augmented thee her misfortunes, was, that he durt not reveal her Sentiments, and unravel her Reentments; But though he durt not let her Rival know her, and revenge her elf upon the brisk Jilt for that injury he received Lycidas mut feel here fury; he cratched and bit him by the hand, Arm, and Face, and pulled him by the Hair, of her ide I mean, and in a word, whereever her Teeth and Nails could reach, he clawed him, as though the Divel were in her, or as though the Divel were in him, and he were to draw blood of the Wizard.

lg.l: Between a loving pair of Ladies lie,
And yet turn neither way?
Fy Lycidas, rie up, both atisfy,
'Tis not impoible, faith try,
And bear the lovely prizes both away.
Thy weet Catholicon will both appeare,
Her lovely Rage, here killing kindnees.
What miery can equal thine,
When Love and Rage to plague thee both combine?
Stretch'd and immoveable he lay,
Like ome dull lump of Clay
Which no brave prightly form did actuate,
Not could the Ladies make him how
His Love or Hate,
For all they with their Lips or Nails could do.
This happy Cheek is kis'd, and kis'd again,
And her weet charming Lips tood hov'ring there
About his Lips, his Eyes, and ev'ry where,
Whence love had loaded here with many a chain
And when her Lips he tole away,
Her whiter Hands began the Play,
And trok'd the Roes in his Cheeks aide,
That nothing like a Bluh might top the Tide
Of their delight, and caue a dull delay.
But then the other ide mut bleeding lie,
And uffer whate'r jealouie,
Can with it's Fury make him do,
She pinch'd his hand, and bit his Lip in two;
Yet till he lies inenible
To tormy Fury, and to milder Love,
Nor could you by his carriage jutly tell
From whence he did the great pleaure prove.
What can we hope from out weet Mitrees,
When in the midt of two uch pretty Creatures
For Wit, & omething ele beides their Features
In deep ditres
Poor Lycidas
Lay like an As
That Vere nor Proe can his ad Grief expres.
For two uch Beauties too inenible,
He can no paion feel,
But in the midt of Heav'n he finds a Hell.

div.p:
But neceity very much heightening his invention, together with that apprehenion, he had, let ome diorder hould happen between
the Rival Ladies, he very nimbly leaped off the Bed, and taking Cephia by the hand; Faith, Madam, aid he I mut be unhappy at preent in pite of all your goodnes, and your Favours mut prove ueles to me; nor can I embrace that happines, which I would at any other time have acrificed my life to have procured. I mut have more prudence than you in this conjuncture, and preerve your Honour at the expence of my pleaures. Come Madam, I mut lead you out of the chamber, and put you out of fear of a urprial; without quetion, Madam, I infinitely oblige you in this, and make you hun an accident, that would trouble you as long as you breathed. He aid no more, but taking her away with a pretty kind of violence, he led her out of the chamber, and having brought her down tairs, he left her at the Hall door, where all the Ladies were till a playing; he, as the was a very neat diembler, humbly thanked him, and confeed he had very much obliged her. But, Sir, the buines above Stairs had not been carried o happily, that Cephia heard nothing of it; he heard omething jut as Lycidas was taking her away, and now mut needs gratify her Curioity, and ee what the matter is; o that Lycidas had no ooner left her, but he followed him very ilently to the Chamber door, where our too kind and loving Cavalier, and no les beloved neither, was carce entred, but Zelotide that had now run mad with jealouie, caught him by the Hair, and with their Teeth, Nails, and Feet, did o handle him, you would have pittied the poor Gentleman.

lg.l: Thus the poor Lycidas's detiny
Made him too late to ee
What a misfortune 'tis,
How dull a blis
To have a furious Lady for a Mis;
Thrice had the Man been Treated thus,
With furious hands, and words more furious.
At lat auming Courage, thus he aid,
Prithee give o're
No more, my Dear, no more,
Thy Fury has enough thy Love betray'd,
I ee, I feel its vehemence,
Too martly does it trike the ene.
I cannot with uch Favours well dipence.
Thus I another imile may prove,
Detroyed by what I firt deired, my Love.
Nay now e'n moderate
Your too much Love, or your pretended Hate.
Let me not have o kind a Mitris,
And if you'l love me, love me les;
Love in exces does to a torment turn,
And what at firt but warm'd, begins to burn.

div.p:
But Lycidas's Remontrance had no great power over Zelotide's oul, her cries were till coutinued, and her Female weapons were till employed in expreing her reentments. All this, Sir, Cephia heard very ditinctly, and thoe bitter reproaches that continually accompanied her aaults, taught the curious Lady what was the caue of the diorder; he knew very well by what he heard Zelotide ay, that her ecret Commerce and Intelligence with Lycidas was
dicovered, and that if the noie he made were heard by any of the houe, all their myteries would come out, and her Honour be ruined eternally. Whereupon, very wiely conidering for ome mall time, he reckoned it an extraordinary piece of prudence, to go and embrace Zalotide, and deire her, ince they knew one anothers intrigues, to live in good intelligence with her, and like good friends very honetly to hare Lycidas betwixt them; Cephia, who was a very jut good natured thing, would have conented to this Treaty with all her oul; but Zelotide was not of o tame a humour to go harers with any one, he mut engros the whole Commodity; and truly in that Rage he then was, a more moderate peron then Zelotide would be mad at uch a Propoition, as really he was, and Treated poor Cephia after the tranget manner that ever was heard of; he immediately left Lycidas, and fell oul upon her Rival, and being incomparable good at kicking, biting, and thoe kind of laudable exercies; he attacked Cephia with o much cruelty, that the poor Lady was neceitated to defend her elf with the ame weapons; Lycidas in the mean time did all he poibly could to part them, but they were o divelih hot at it, that all his endeavors proved ineffectual the noie of this formidable and mot dreadful engagement, was preently heard by ome of the Family, and they very diligently, and with all the peed they could, acquainted the company, o that in an intant, the greatet part of them, ran
thither with lights, to dicover the unknown adventure.

lg.l: Where the two Rivals did enrag'd appear,
Without or Wit or Fear,
Their Eyes did in their parkling Dialect,
Their Rage detect.
Whilt from thoe ources of bright light their prings
Far other Darts than thoe that conquer kings.
They with an equal Rage are both poes'd,
She claw'd her Rivals naked Breat,
And with pure blood checker'd her whiter Chet.
But th'other then had lot her Hood,
And her fine trees did dihe vel'd fall,
By which her Rival drags her to the Wall,
And o revenges all her los of Blood.
But then her Point is gone,
And her new Locks are down,
And her pure Pendants cattered on the ground
Beides he 'as lot her Necklace;
Nor did the controverted Lover,
Though they both lov'd him, urffer les
They crach'd him, threw him down, and tumbled over.
Six wounds he had all bleeding till,
Whence did that bloud ditill,
Could the impatient Jilts have taid,
Would have their fiercenes and their Rage allay'd.
Well tir'd he was and bloudy too,
As well he might, after all this adoe,
And all 'caue one was not enough for two.
Then for the Field where all this bloud was pilt
By one and th' other Jilt,
'Tis richly worth your obervation too,
'Twas wondrous pretty, & I'le wear 'twas new
There lay Bracelets, Pearls, and Amber,
All pread about the Chamber,
Two Gloves at two yards ditance lay,
Thoe white Inviters to o black a Fray,
There lay their Head dres,
That they had plac'd before with ch a dres,
Three Cuffs, if I remember too, there was
Among which lay Lycidas
Hit new white Wigg, half tore to pieces,
(What a ad misfortune this is)

div.p:
There was a great deal more worth your Royal Highnees Obervation, if I could remember it. But this may uffice to perwade you, that it was the prettiet Scene imaginable. The firt care that the pectators took upon them, was to part the Combatants; but the diorder, had proceeded farther, had not ome peaceable perons among them took up the buines. For the Husbands being got half fudled, without examination, ran on like mad caps to take their Wives parts, o that the Battle was beginning again as bloudily as ever, and had continued o, had not the Mater of the Houe, with the aitance of ome Friends, and Kindred, mediated betwixt them, and treated a ceation from Arms on both parties, until the caue of the quarrel could be known. They asked
Cephia, and asked Zelotide what occaioned their engagement, but neither of them anwer'd a word to purpoe, but continued colding at one another, as though they had been brought up at Billing sgate, and tood ix times in the Cucking-tool; Lycidas, that had always a very quick invention in uch conjunctures, and never pumpt for a lie in his life, aw all was lot, if he did not light on ome uddain expedient, to bring all off again, and conceal their Miteries, and ave his Ladies reputation. His prightly imagination immediately furnihed him with the happiet device in the world; whereupon he offered to inform the company of the true caue of the diorder; and when he aw them all keep ilence, he told them, That Cephia and Zelotide (as ill luck would have it) had ome buines at the ame time to go up the ame pair of Stairs, and that they went up with o much precipitation, that they had not time to call for a light; that in the dark, not eeing one another, they chanced at the Stair-head to jutle very furiouly; And that having no good will for one another, as all the Town knows, they took it for an abue: And thereupon came to words about it, and from words to blows, o that he lying in chamber hard by, whither he bad retired from the Debauch, to leep a little, was awaked by their noie, and went out to end the quarrel; That he had by main force brought one of the Ladies into hit Chamber, to keep her from her Enemy; But that the other had purued her o furiouly, and they both continued o obtinate in their fighting humour, that they had
treated one another jut o as they aw, and had put him in that condition they found him in, for endeavouring to part them.

While Lycidas was carrying on his relation, the Rival-Ladies came to themselves a little, and began to fear, leat the ubject of their quarrel hould be dicovered; but eeing, Sir, how ingeniouly their common Lover had excued them, and brought all off again, they avow'd all he aid, and made a fit ue of his probable excues. She jutled me, cryed one, and he jutled me aid the other,; and were o hot at it preently, that their friends came to hold them in, let they hould again commence the combate. But the Mater of the Houe, and ome other friends that Tere there, eaily quieted this econd emotion, and remedied the relape. I hey told the two intereed Gentlemen, that no body was injured, that all was by meer chance, and that the blows were o equally divided, that neither could boat of her ucces, The age and prudent Husbands having very gravely heard all the particulars, were the firt perons that laughed at the adventure, and wore their Wives were as drunk as they were, and called the Female combatants Fools, and Goips, and God knows what; but begged Lycidas's pardon a thouand times over, made him all the excues they could think on, engaged their fighting Beauties to make Lycidas atisfaction for the injury he had received, and without more ado reeled to their debauch again. The two Rival-Ladies embraced one another, at the requet of
the company of the Women, and were overjoyed in o dangerous a conjuncture, at the preervation of their Honour, they laughed as heartily as the ret, at the pleaant extravagance of their quarrel, and told it jut o as Lycidas had done before them.

The Husbands being got pretty well drunk by this time, and the Ladies having, laughed their laugh out, all the company went to bed, and among the ret, the Bride and her Gentleman; for though I told you they went to bed before, you mut know that they poor ouls roe again, and came to ee another kind of combat then what they were engaged in, but now the Company once again brought them together, where we hall leave them, for I think we cannot leave them better: On the morrow the company parted, having firt agreed, and judged it requiite, that the two reconciled Ladies, Cephia and Zelotide hould go to Town in the ame Coach; and their Husbands fearing leat Lycidas had not heartily pardoned them for all the cratches, together with the bites and bruies he had received, would by all means perwade him to go along with them, without any other oul with him, but his two Mitrees; and thee good obliging Cornutos charged their Wives to pacify him too, and do all they could to procure his pardon.

lg.l: Thus do thoe civil Gentlemen
Sometimes our pleaure, and our joys advance
They hug their Ladies Favourite, and then
Commend the pretty ouls into their hands.
Thoe horn-mad Cuckolds now are out of date
That would the Courtly Gallant hate
That Poions, Swords, and Halters threaten till
And to do more than kill,
And vindicate their Honour on that Head
That had (for o they peak) defil'd their Bed,
When as kind ouls they did but all they cou'd,
To pleae their Ladies at expence of Blood,
And do that Drudgery the Husbands hou'd.
No; our obliging Generation
Will no uch troubleom crack'd fools admit,
It has more Sene and Wit,
Then till to blame that Act that mut be done.
If a good Husband hould dicover
His Lady's Lover
He ne'r wou'd make a word of it,
'Twould be mot cured candalous
To quetion what he does,
Prove him a Clown, no Courtier, nor no Wit.
No, he himelf wou'd their content procure,
And never trouble their Amour,
He lets her meet him when he will,
And both of one another have their fill;
He may his Lady then more eaily
Content and atisfy,
For he alone he's ure can never do it,
Should he but rigorouly hold him to it.
Thus he what e're her carriage be
Though he her viits and carees ee.
Still obtinately blind, will nought dicover,
And though he ees, yet will not ee a Lover.

div.p: Our Galllant and the two Rival-Ladies being now together in the ame Coach, your Royal Highnes may eaily conjecture, after o pleaant an adventure; that their converation was not unpleaant, and that a great many fine things were poken amongt them. Lycidas began to make them ee their imprudence, and told them, if his addres had not helpt them out at a dead lift, their extravagance might have had very bad conequences; both the Ladies were of his opinion, and rendered him their hearty thanks for o high an obligation. And now they were in uch a condition, that they could no longer conceal their affairs from one another, o that by the mediation of Lycidas, they were made very good friends again, and there pat between them the finet Raillery, but yet the mot civil and innocent, about their Loves, that ever was heard. Cephia told Zelotide of her jealouie, and Zelotide rally'd on Cephia for being content with her leavings, and all this had o little harhnes in it, and was o extreamly and obliging, that two Rivals were never yet more fully reconciled then they.

lg.l: What marvels did ingenious Love then do?
Love like the States could then admit of more,
While the fair Prize was har'd between the two.
This was a wonder never een before.
The pains and pleaures they do both partake,
And willingly their common chain endure.
Friendhip from Hate he did with eae procure
That did at firt their pirits captive make.
Since in one common third they both agre,
Let one the Lover of the other be.

div.p: Before they came to Town, they very olemnly covenanted, the better to ilence the impertinent Lampooners of the Town, and to cheat their Husbands the more dexterouly, to part Lycidas betwixt them, as a good that was equally common to both of them. They moreover fully reolved and agreed to do all they poibly could, to hinder any third Lady from robbing them of o agreeable a Treaure. And that if through any Caprichio of his he hould favour the one more then the other, the agrieved Lady hould not make any publick diturbance about it, and that all the Arms he hould make ue of to retrieve the fugitive, hould be carees and obligations, Thee condition thus formerly agreed on, were o advantagious for Lycidas, that he could not with reaon refue them, as really he did not. But aured his two Ladies, that he was very well atisfied with them, and wore he would never on his part violate the Articles.

For ome weeks the two Rivals, with the happy third peron, the beloved Lycidas lived in very good intelligence, according to the conditions agreed upon in the lat Treaty. The Ladies were infinitely happy, and thought themelves
o too, but Lycidas began to urfet on their goodnes, and was preently cloy'd With o much weetnes. This good intelligence of theirs plagued him mot unmercifully, and at lat he found by ad experience, that he might with les difficulty content his two Mitrees during their diviion, then now he had made them friends, Thee two handome perons loved one another with as great a paion, as they hated each other formerly, they were never out of one anothers company, and that former precaution of Lycidas's, that he had before o crupulouly oberved, and that the obervance of o much, troubled him, became now ueles and inignificant.

lg.l: Thus when the one py'd with what gallantry,
He did his Love unto her friend addres,
She never wih'd it les,
But knew he'd make her happy by and by;
When he exactly how'd the ame confer
As much as to a glance or word on her,
She never blam'd her Rivals kies
Nor envy'd thoe more great and olid blies
Since by and by
She the same Gallantry
Mut without diminution enjoy.

div.p:
This accurate kind of ditributive jutice was mighty troubleome to the too too much beloved Lycidas; and I eaily perward my elf that as well ton'd as he was of endearing carees, (and truly, Sir, I believe few perons in
France could vie with him) all his tock would have been oon exhauted, and he have been reduced to extream beggery, and if there had not come an Order from his Majety to change his Garrion, and lead his Regiment into a Citadel, upon the frontiers of picardy. How agreeable this Order was to Lycidas, that was now even tired and more then atiated with their amorous Delicates, your Royal Highnes may eaily conjecture; but the poor Ladies were truck dead with the dreadful news, all the Thunders in nature could not have o much diturbed their ouls; but in fine, there was an abolute neceity for their enduring of it; the King mut be obeyed, and they mut loe their Lycidas. Lycidas went to take his farwel of them, when they were both together, and this ad farwel of his, cot the poor Ladies a multinude of Tears, and Lycidas hed ome too, though I believe, out of a very different conideration, and they were only Tears of joy for the recovery of his liberty, and his diingagement from o troubleome a happines, while his ad Mitrees wept mot exceively, and cared not to preerve the glories of their bright Circles, when the only Man they eteemed in the world had deerted them, and they could ee nothing now worth the captivating: They entreated him to honour them with a viit as oon as poibly he could, and to return the ame Lycidas to their embraces, that he was with that ame prightly Air, and Gayety of his, and above all, with that ardent paion (for
o they call'd it) he was pleaed to have for them. Lycidas promied them mot liberally, all they could deire, but I can aure your Royal Highnes, that to this moment he never performed a word of thee his promies, and it is now above nine months ince he left them. He himelf was pleaed to tell me this tory, and withall he aur'd me, that there were very handome and courtly Officers in that Regiment that came to relieve them, and perons that without doubt were capable to undertake any amorous adventure. As oon as they have changed their Garrion, I do not quetion but ome one or other among them will bring us more news of Zelotide, and her extravagant Jealouie.

And now, Sir, I hall own the ambition, to ay, I hope as well as wih, that my Zelotide, with all her faults, may have the happines to pleae your Royal Highnes, which if I hall be once aured of, my Mue tirred up by o glorious an encouragement, and o brave a ucces, hall till continue in her deign of diverting your Royal Highnes. Our French Gallantries are o frequent and uual, that I hall never want a ubject for Stories of this nature, and they always are in themelves o pleaant and agreeable, that they can't chue but take, if the Hitorian poils not their native graces. What an Honour hall I be bleed with, if this foolery of mine hall prove fortunate enough to pleae your Royal Highnes! and what an infinite joy hould I reent, if my Pen at your Commands were employed in writing a more erious Hitory!
Could I be the happy eye-witnes of o glorious a life as yours, and be then Commanded to tranmit it to poterity, adorned with all its noble circumtances, I perwade my elf, Sir, that o brave a Subject would inpire me with new flights, and that my tyle advanced and lifted up with the Dignity of o great a Subject, would never flag, but keep up its excellence with an equal force continually. If this wih, Sir, be rah and foolih, as with a bluh I cannot but avow it is, I humbly beg your Royal Highnes will be pleaed to pardon it, and impute it to my Zeal for your Royal Highnes's ervice, and to permit my Mues to confer omething to your divertiement, and vouchafe me the glory to tell all the world, that I am,

closer.signed: Your R. Highnes's Mot Humble, and Obedient Servant, LE PAYS.
